articles.title: 2025 P1 Registration: Key Dates For Registering Your Child For Primary School In Singapore
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: The 2025 P1 Registration Exercise for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents will begin on Tuesday, 1 July 2025. Here’s all you need to know to register your child. Families interested in registering their children born between 2 January 2019 and 1 January 2020 (both dates inclusive) for local primary school should take note of the ongoing P1 registration 2025 exercise . All 2025 P1 registrations will be conducted online as it was in the past years, and there will not be any in-person registration at schools. 2025 P1 registration is conducted over several phases: Phase 1, 2A, 2B and 2C Supplementary apply to children who are Singapore Citizens (SC) and Permanent Residents (PR). Phase 3 is for international students. If your child is Singaporean or Permanent Resident and has an older sibling already enrolled in a local primary school, parents are required to submit an application directly to the school from 9am on Tuesday, 1 July 2025 to 4:30am on Thursday, 3 July 2025 (Phase 1 of the 2025 P1 registration process). The primary school where the older sibling is currently studying will provide parents with more details on how to register their younger child. For Phases 2A, 2B and 2C, the link to the online form and user guide will be available on the MOE 2025 P1 Registration website during the registration periods of the respective phases. Key dates for P1 Registration 2025 Phase 1: 1 July, 9am to 3 July, 4.30pm Phase 2A: 10 July, 9am to 11 July, 4.30pm Phase 2B: 21 July 9am to 22 July, 4.30pm Phase 2C: 29 July 9am to 31 July, 4.30pm Phase 2C Supplementary: 18 August, 9am to 19 August, 4.30pm 2 schools with cap on intake of PR kids for 2025 P1 Registration MOE announced in 2020 that there will be a 25 to 30% cap on the intake of PR children at select primary schools , for Phases 2C and 2C Supplementary only so as to “encourage interaction between Singapore citizens and PR children, and facilitate the integration of PR children into Singapore.” For the 2025 P1 Registration Exercise, there is a PR cap for the following schools: – Bukit Timah Primary School – Cantonment Primary School Are international students eligible for 2025 P1 registration? Image credit: Ministry of Education, Singapore via Facebook If you are neither a Singaporean citizen nor PR, note that all non-PR foreigners are required to complete an “online indication of interest,” which will only be live from here from 9am on Tuesday, 27 May 2025 to 4.30pm on Monday, 2 June 2025, otherwise you will not be able to register in Phase 3 of the P1 Registration Exercise. Info on documents needed here . International students (IS) can only register for P1 during Phase 3 of the P1 Registration Exercise, after all Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents have been allocated a place under the earlier phases. You will be notified by October 2025 whether your child can be offered a P1 place. Check out the Ministry of Education’s specific instructions here Read More: Why we chose local Singapore schools for our expat kids FAQs for 2025 P1 Registration Image credit: MOE 1. After registering interest in June 2025 what comes next? In October 2025 , families selected by MOE as eligible to register will be contacted to bring ALL original documents listed below in person to a designated school for verification. Take note that both parents’ original passports and identity cards will be required so manage travel plans accordingly. More info on documents needed here . 2. How can I update my child’s vaccinations and check what is required? Regarding vaccinations: To update all vaccination records, you can scan and email all vaccinations along with the child’s FIN number, full name to the Health Promotion Board at hpb_nir@hpb.gov.sg . Click here to see the Singapore vaccination schedule 3. How can I improve my odds of getting a spot in a local school? Admission to local schools for foreigners (children without PR or citizenship) is decided at the discretion of the Ministry of Education. All families can do is follow the process by the deadline, submit the required documentation, and hope for a favourable outcome. 4. I hear that even if I am PR, I won’t get a spot in a local school. This is untrue. All children holding PR or citizenship are guaranteed a spot in a local school. Be sure to review the registration by phases to learn the steps required if your child is not a foreigner. 5. How do I get into a “good school” as a foreigner? Admission to local schools and choice of schools for foreigners (children without PR or citizenship) is decided at the discretion of the Ministry of Education. Read more: Expat Reflections after a Year in Local Singapore Primary School 6. I am PR but my child is not, what do we do? You register during the Phase 3 registration as a non-PR foreigner. The immigration status of the child signals the phase of registration, regardless of the status of the parent. 7. What if our application is denied? This is a likely outcome. All decisions are final and appeals are not considered. All families should prepare a backup plan for the education of their child should the local school application not succeed. Read more: Guide to International Secondary Schools in Singapore 8. Can I register next year? Foreigners wanting to register outside of the P1 registration phases will have to take a rigorous standardised test called the AEIS and admission is at the discretion of the Singapore government. For more information consult the Ministry of Education. Click here to read about one mama’s experience when her son took the AEIS. 9. I want to register my child for a local school, but they were not born between 2 January 2019 and 1 January 2020 Outside of the P1 registration, all foreign children applying for a local school must take the AEIS exam. Admission to the school is at the discretion of the Singapore government. For more information, consult the Ministry of Education ! 10. What happens if I missed the phase my child is eligible for? You can still register your child in the next eligible phase, but there will be no priority given. If you missed the 2025 P1 Registration Exercise completely and do not have approval from the MOE for deferment, you can contact the MOE to enrol your child into a school with vacancies. More Resources: Singapore Expats in Local Schools Facebook Group Singapore Expat Schooling Forum Facebook Group Kiasu Parents (for school ranking) Read more: The post 2025 P1 Registration: Key Dates For Registering Your Child For Primary School In Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama .

articles.title: This Bali Resort Has A 17,000sqft Kids’ Playground & Exclusive Perks For Guests
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: RIMBA by AYANA introduces the new RIMBA Jungle Adventure, a massive playground spanning over 17,000sqft. With access to all of AYANA Bali’s resort facilities and stunning cliffside views, here’s why you should plan your next family vacay here. Holidaying with the kids always brings about two big questions: What’s fun for the kids? And how do the adults get to squeeze in their own fun? Well, we can attest that you can check both boxes off at AYANA Bali . Tucked away on a cliff overlooking Jimbaran Bay, AYANA Bali comprises a cluster of four award-winning luxury resorts. Stay at any of these resorts and you’ll get access to the facilities of all four resorts, which is why you’ll never run out of things to do here. Now, the resort introduces its latest addition: the massive RIMBA Jungle Adventure at RIMBA by AYANA, with a playground that spans over 17,000sqft. With rates from $226/night*, here’s why this resort makes a failproof getaway for the family: *Rate based on the lowest nightly rate during the summer 2025 season at the time of writing. New indoor & outdoor playgrounds for young explorers It’s always a win when a resort has a playground. Now, make it very, very large and filled with exploration, and you’ll be left with happy kiddos who’ll remember this holiday for years to come. That said, the newly-launched RIMBA Jungle Adventure has everything you can imagine to delight kids of all ages: an outdoor playground with a web of climbing structures, slides, zip lines and more; and an indoor section with a ball pit and even more slides–all packed with adventure, learning and imaginative play. August 2025 will also see the opening of AYANA Ocean Adventure, where kids can cool off with fun water play and ocean exploration, and Tevana Playground, another park with a playground for even more exploration! Access to 14 pools, private beach, Rock Bar & more What we love about AYANA Bali is that no matter which resort you’re staying at, you’ll get access to almost all the facilities of the other AYANA Bali resorts. And trust us, it’s worth exploring. Guests get access to 14 swimming pools, including an infinity pool, a river pool, kids’ pools, cabanas and more. There’s also the secluded Kubu Beach located on a quiet cove with amazing views of the cliffs along the coastline. All-access also means you get to peruse both kids’ playgrounds at AYANA Resort Bali and RIMBA by AYANA. Families can also participate in fun workshops such as crafts and cooking, local experiences such as farm tours, and nature walks around the resort grounds. There’s plenty for Mum and Dad, too! An array of wellness and fitness activities, including yoga, sound baths and 24/7 fitness centres, are at your disposal. Pamper yourself at one of the three spas: one on a cliff, another overlooking the sea, and one right by the shore, with rejuvenating facilities such as a Thalassotherapy pool. When tummies are rumbling, head to one of the 30 restaurants across the four resorts. You can find just about every cuisine you could crave, from fresh seafood to Italian, steak, Japanese and more, with kid-friendly options. Guests also get access to the iconic Rock Bar, situated atop the rocky shore, boasting arguably the best sunset views in Bali. Get up to 20% off ‘The Perfect Family Getaway’ Of course, there are perks for you! For a fuss-free experience, book ‘The Perfect Family Getaway’ and you’ll get up to 20% off your room rate with breakfast, plus resort credit. Make your booking from now till 30 June 2025, for stays till 20 December 2025 (minimum of two nights required), and you’ll get these benefits: Resort credit IDR 300,000 for AYANA Resort, AYANA Segara, AYANA Villas Bali / IDR 200,000 for RIMBA by AYANA Bali. One time Pizza and a Glass of beer at AYANA or RIMBA pools for 2 people. One time 3-course set Lunch or Dinner for 2 adults at selected restaurants (minimum stay of 4 nights). 10% Spa discount on in-room treatments and Spa on the Rocks treatments. 10% Discount on food and beverages, including Rock Bar, Bali. The next time you’re looking for a family getaway in Bali, check out the resorts at AYANA Bali and its fab kid-friendly facilities. Just be warned: they may not want to leave! Get up to 20% off rooms with breakfast + resort credit when you reserve here . articles.title: Father’s Day Gift Ideas In Singapore 2025 For Every Type Of Dad
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Father’s Day 2025 is Sunday, 15 June 2025 so there’s plenty of time to think about gifts. No matter what sort of dad Papa is, we’ve got a Father’s Day gift to suit him. Looking for a Father’s Day gift? Father’s Day in Singapore is Sunday, 15 June 2025, and just like for Mother’s Day , we are here to provide you with the best gifts for the occasion! Gift Dad a custom-made mug or portrait illustration or treat your partner to a relaxing massage or a destressing experience in a rage room. From super gadgets like cheaper alternatives to the Go Pro, to nifty drones, cooking gadgets and the latest Nintendo games, there is something for every dad in our roundup of best Father’s Day gifts for 2025! Read More: Restaurants to Book for a Father’s Day Meal Father’s Day Gift Ideas In Singapore 2025: 1. Start Father’s Day with Breakfast in Bed Image credit: Pexels Who says that breakfast in bed and flowers are only for mamas? This Father’s Day, get fathers their very own brekkie in bed and some pretty blooms. From pancakes to healthy muffins , there are so many things that you can cook – and the kids can help too. If you are looking for a florist check out our guide for florists in Singapore. 2. Stylish Father’s Day Gift: Swimwear Image credit: Tom & Teddy (left) | Vilebrequin (right) Swimwear is such a practical Father’s Day Gift in Singapore since lots of family condos have a pool and there are a tonne of water parks and public swimming pools to check out with the kids. We love the matchy-matchy Father & Son prints from Vilebrequin but they are on the pricey end – check out more matching swimwear for kids and adults here ! More affordable swimwear can be found at Ocean Paradise-check out the Tom & Teddy range . 3. Father’s Day Gift for Cooks: Meater Thermometer Image credit: Meater If Dad is a whizz in the kitchen (or a wannabe whizz) invest in some cooking gadgets that will make BBQs and cooking meat a whole lot simpler! Meater is a standalone wireless, smart meat thermometer that cooks meat to absolute perfection with real time cooking data through an app. This nifty device satisfies dads’ love of gadgets and it will get those prime steaks and ribs cooked just the way you like – never undercook or overcook that expensive piece of meat again. 4. Father’s Day Present for photography enthusiasts Image credit: DJI – Action Father’s Day Gift for gadget lovers: DJI Action 3 Been contemplating a GoPro to gift Dad for Father’s Day? We have heard amazing reviews for the DJI Action 3 – a 4K action camera alternative to the GoPro Hero 11. The quality is superb and comes with some cool underwater features such as scuba diving mode (auto white balancing) and crucially costs around $100 less than the GoPro Hero 11! 5. Perfect Gift for Dads on the Go: Wireless Earphones Image credit: Pexels – Apple Airpods Wireless earphones are all the rage. And, for a good reason! Great for listening to podcasts, music or doing work calls on the go – making them the perfect Father’s Day gift for busy dads who are constantly out and about! From AirPods to Beats Fit Pro, there are countless different brands. For Apple users, the AirPods are the way to go as it syncs seamlessly with the iPhone. If your partner loves to listen to music and exercise, then the Jabra Elite series is what you should get. With so many options, there is sure to be a perfect wireless earphone gift for every budget and need! 6. articles.title: “My Helper & Daughter Would Say ‘I Love You’ To Each Other In Burmese”
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: “When I broke the news to my daughter that our helper was leaving, she was silent and stared off into space, refusing to look at me or let me touch her. My little 4-year-old couldn’t process that her ‘best friend’ Aunty Min would likely never return.” “Mama,” my 4-year-old daughter Lana called me, as she came into my room. “Aunty Min is crying,” she said about my helper, Min. A million thoughts ran through my head: Was it heartbreak? Did something happen to a family member? Could she be … pregnant? It’s okay, I thought. We’ve gotten through her appendicitis, getting cheated on by her boyfriend, losing her grandmother, and more in the past. We surely can get through this, right? “Ma’am,” Min approached me, trembling, when I came out of the room. She reached out and held my hand, and my heart dropped. I held my breath. “Ma’am. I’m so sorry, Ma’am. I need to go back to Myanmar … for my family,” she said, tears streaming down her face. I said, “It’s okay, Min…” “Ma’am, you and Sir have been so good to me, I’m so sorry,” she broke down sobbing and pulled me into a hug. I knew at that moment there was little chance we could convince her to stay. My helper of three years was really leaving, even though she was happy with us. And although it had only been a relatively short time, Min was part of our family and shared a special bond with my daughter Lana. Here’s our story with our unexpected angel, who saved our family from falling apart when we were at our most vulnerable. Read more: All About Helper Appreciation In Singapore We initially didn’t want a helper Image credit: Freepik Min was the first and only helper we interviewed. We had zero experience with having a helper in Singapore , but we were desperate at that time. Min spoke little to no English, but we ended up hiring her off “good vibes”. We had initially been reluctant to hire a helper. Plenty of people around me seemed to be able to do without (with multiple kids, mind you!), and we didn’t feel comfortable with having a “stranger” living in our home. I was also nervous about how Lana would adapt, seeing that she was extremely clingy with me. But with my husband’s airline pilot roster and my severe lack of a “village” in Singapore, we were struggling to hold everything together. Lana was a very spritely 1.5-year-old, and I was working full-time. Yes, we sent her to a childcare centre during the day, but on the days she fell sick and stayed home, it was impossible for me to get any work or chores done. With my husband often away–or recuperating from flights–my life was 24/7 childcare, work and chores. My social life and my me-time became nonexistent. I won’t go into the details, but the complete loss of identity and stress of managing everything on my own eventually began to eat away at my mental health. Not to mention, spiralling into petty arguments with my husband. After nights of breaking down and many, many talks about how we were going to improve our situation, we finally gave in and started looking for a helper to take some of the load off my shoulders. Read more: ‘There’s a protective mama bear part of me who just wants her kids to herself.’ How my helper became my “co-parent” Image credit: freepic.diller via Freepik Min naturally seemed nervous when she arrived. I showed her around the house, gave her a rundown of her duties, and showed her what needed to be done. She pretty much got to work right away. Then, in the evening when Lana came home from childcare, Min’s eyes lit up. Lana was often shy around strangers, but Min approached her and started playing with her, singing nursery rhymes and letting Lana show her her toys. Lana warmed up quickly. It turned out we were going to be okay. Lana and Min bonded and got along like a house on fire. Eventually, Min was able to step in when I needed help with mealtimes, bath time and bedtime. After over a year and a half of never having gone out without Lana or spending all my free time cleaning, I was able to regain some freedom. I was able to meet friends for dinner, go on date nights with my husband, or simply have an extra pair of hands to mind Lana when I was tied up or overwhelmed. Min was always delighted to spend time with Lana, treating her as if she were her own. In fact, she was rather overprotective of Lana, always keeping a close eye on her safety when she was playing or climbing around. There were times I even felt a little envious of their relationship–Lana often preferred for Min to carry her, feed her, bathe her and play with her. They had their own inside jokes and conversations filled with huge laughter. Some may say I didn’t set boundaries, but Min and Lana would say “I love you” to each other in Burmese. She even taught Lana how to count and say other basic phrases in Burmese. I quickly brushed that feeling of envy off, as I knew I’d always be Lana’s Mummy and that I was extremely lucky to have a helper who genuinely cared for my child. With Min now sharing my parenting load, it very much felt like she was my co-parent. Of course, Min and I still had that employee-employer boundary, but we cared for each other. Whenever I was sick, Min would make sure to ask if I needed anything and then spring into action to mind Lana so I could rest. Likewise, we always ensured that Min knew she had us for support: we talked through her heartbreak, family problems and more. We always got each other gifts during special occasions and included her in all of our family celebrations, and she would bring back her favourite Burmese desserts for us when she went back to visit her family. My husband and I would also often chat with her about her life and her family back home. Min is not married and has no kids, and is extremely close with her mum and siblings. She had even set up a small business back home to support her siblings and niece. It was obvious that Min was the rock of her family and that everything she does is for them. Saying goodbye to our unexpected angel Image credit: jcomp via Freepik Min was delighted to renew her contract after two years, and we always hoped that she would stay with us long-term. But that wasn’t in the cards for us. Min’s family was experiencing some hardships back in Myanmar, and they needed her to be with them. We knew that she wouldn’t be able to continue working in Singapore with such a weight on her shoulders. Family always comes first, we say, and so we supported her decision to leave. I didn’t expect myself to feel so devastated when the reality of her leaving hit me. When I broke the news to Lana that Min was leaving, Lana was silent and stared off into space, refusing to look at me or let me touch her. My little 4-year-old couldn’t process that her “best friend” would likely never return. I explained to Lana that her Aunty Min had to go home to her family, and that we’ll always be thankful for having had her around these past three years. Lana then went to Min’s room to give her a hug, before breaking down and crying inconsolably. “We still have time,” I told Lana, “Let’s just enjoy the last couple of months we have with Aunty Min, okay?” Lana cried herself to sleep in my arms that night. The next day, she seemed to be back to normal, and so we carried on with our lives, periodically reminding Lana that her Aunty Min was leaving soon and that we’d have a new Aunty around. Lana seems to have accepted that Min is leaving, and we’re prepared for an adjustment period once our new helper arrives . Min is leaving in a few days’ time, and there’s an obvious skip in her step. There’s also a heaviness in her–she’s happy that she will finally get to be with her family, but she’s also dreading the day she has to part ways with Lana. Due to the current situation in Myanmar, as well as Min’s family situation, it is unlikely that Min will ever return to work in Singapore. As for my husband and me, we will always appreciate how Min became such an unexpected but amazing part of our little family. I don’t know if she realises just how much she did for us, but I made sure to let her know how grateful we were. We will always appreciate how, back in Myanmar, there’ll be a hardworking 30-year-old Min who has a heart of pure gold, is exceptionally resourceful and smart, who always puts others before herself, and who helped us get through one of our most vulnerable times. Read more: How To Help Your Child Say Goodbye To Your Helper The post “My Helper & Daughter Would Say ‘I Love You’ To Each Other In Burmese” appeared first on Sassy Mama .

articles.title: Meet The Mum Of Two Behind Singapore’s Largest Indoor Playgrounds, Heidi Tian
articles.author: Jessica Fang
articles.content: She built the largest indoor playground in Singapore, and then 10 more across four countries. We chat with Heidi Tian, the founder and CEO of Kiztopia, about motherhood and what it’s like seeing her childhood vision of play come to life. Before moving to Singapore, Heidi Tian was deep in the world of banking—think long hours and fast-paced cities. But after becoming a mum, her priorities started to shift. She wanted more balance, and when she got to Singapore in 2012, something clicked: where were the big, fun, indoor play spaces for kids? That question planted the seed for Kiztopia . Leaving behind a steady corporate job to start something from scratch wasn’t easy—there were delays, tough calls and plenty of unknowns. But when she walked into her first completed playground, filled with colour, exploration and wide-eyed kids, it all felt worth it. We speak to Heidi about how her childhood inspired her love for play and exploration, how she started one of the region’s largest indoor playground chains (Kiztopia has 18 outlets across Singapore, Hong Kong, Thailand and Malaysia!), and what drives her as a parent. Read our past That Mama interviews here . What was your life like before moving to Singapore in 2012? Before moving to Singapore, I spent most of my career in banking, working in the fast-paced financial hubs of the U.S., China, and Hong Kong. While I enjoyed the structured corporate world, becoming a mother shifted my priorities. I found myself searching for more ways to balance career ambitions with family life. When I moved to Singapore, I noticed a gap in the market where there weren’t many large-scale indoor play experiences that combined fun with learning. That realisation ultimately planted the seed for Kiztopia. Having lived in the U.S., China and Hong Kong previously, what are the biggest differences you’ve noticed about raising kids there vs. in Singapore? Every country has a unique parenting culture. In the United States, there’s a strong emphasis on outdoor exploration and fostering independence. In China, structured learning plays a more significant role, and in Hong Kong, limited space means play is often centred around smaller activity zones. Singapore offers an ideal mix: it’s safe, has excellent infrastructure, and encourages both academic excellence and recreational play. Image credit: Kiztopia The pressure of stepping into entrepreneurship from your corporate role must’ve been high. What were some of your most challenging moments, and what were your biggest motivators during that time? Stepping into entrepreneurship was both exhilarating and daunting. One of the biggest challenges was taking that first leap, leaving behind the stability of my corporate career and stepping into the unknown. The early days were filled with uncertainty, from securing the right locations to designing an entirely new concept that stood out in the market. There were moments when things didn’t go as planned—delays, operational hurdles, and the immense responsibility of leading a team. Despite these challenges, my biggest motivator was the vision of what Kiztopia could become. I believed deeply in creating a space where children could learn and grow through play. Seeing families enjoy our playgrounds and hearing parents share how Kiztopia has become a special part of their children’s lives made every challenge worthwhile. Another major source of strength came from my team and my family. Their unwavering support, belief and shared passion for our mission kept me going even in the toughest moments. Read more: Kiztopia Marina Square Review What was your first reaction when you saw your first completed Kiztopia playground at Marina Square? It was an unforgettable moment—both surreal and incredibly emotional. After months of planning, designing, and overcoming countless obstacles, seeing the finished space come to life was overwhelming. I remember walking through the doors, taking in every detail—the vibrant play areas, the intricate designs, and the sheer scale of what we had created. It was a powerful mix of pride, relief, and excitement. But the most fulfilling part was seeing children running in with wide-eyed wonder and hearing their laughter fill the space. That was the moment I knew we had created something special. It wasn’t just about building a playground; it was about bringing joy, fostering imagination, and creating a place where families could bond. That first Kiztopia at Marina Square set the foundation for everything that followed, and even today, I still feel that same sense of excitement whenever we open a new outlet. Image credit: Kiztopia When it comes to conceptualising indoor playgrounds, what’s your go-to for inspiration? A lot of my inspiration comes from being a parent myself. I constantly think about the kind of space I would want for my own children—safe, engaging, and designed to support learning. I also travel frequently to explore different play concepts worldwide. Inspiration also comes from observing how children play, listening to parents, and staying attuned to global trends in family entertainment. Travel remains a huge source of inspiration, as seeing how other countries approach play and design sparks new ideas that we can adapt and innovate upon. Ultimately, the biggest inspiration comes from the children themselves—their curiosity, creativity, and boundless energy drive me to keep pushing boundaries. What are some places you’ve travelled to that have truly impressed you? Japan’s deep appreciation for storytelling is woven into every aspect of play, design, and experience. From iconic brands like Pokémon and Studio Ghibli to immersive attractions such as Disneyland Tokyo and Universal Studios Japan, storytelling is at the heart of engagement. Even in public spaces, interactive experiences—like teamLab Borderless and creative playgrounds—encourage imagination and exploration. Similarly, Taiwan has a strong culture of blending education with entertainment. Places like Taipei’s children’s museums and themed experiential spaces create engaging environments where kids can learn through play. The emphasis on interactive storytelling and multi-sensory experiences reinforces the idea that play should be both enriching and fun. Visiting these countries reinforced my belief that play should be more than just physical activity; it should spark creativity, evoke emotions, and leave lasting memories. At Kiztopia, we aim to bring that same sense of wonder to families by crafting experiences that go beyond play—where every child can embark on their adventure and create stories of their own. Image credit: Kiztopia I’d love to hear more about your childhood. What were your best play/playground memories? Growing up in Xi’an, my childhood was all about outdoor adventures. There weren’t many structured playgrounds, so my best memories were of running freely in open spaces, climbing trees, and making up games with friends. I especially loved visiting parks with vast green fields, lakes, and winding trails—places that felt endless and full of possibility. Nature played a huge role in my childhood. Some of my fondest moments were hiking with my family, breathing in the fresh air, and taking in the beauty of the landscapes around us. Those experiences instilled in me a deep love for exploration and adventure. They taught me that play wasn’t just about having fun—it was about discovery, creativity, and creating lifelong memories. How would you describe your parenting style? I’d say I’m a mix of hands-on and giving them space to grow. I believe in setting strong foundations, but also allowing my children the independence to make their own choices and learn from them. Encouragement, trust, and open communication are at the heart of my approach. What are some of your favourite rituals with your family today? No matter how busy my schedule gets, I try to carve out dedicated family time. Weekend breakfasts are a cherished tradition where we slow down and connect. Traveling together is another highlight, allowing us to bond and create memories. And, of course, play remains a part of our lives—whether through board games, outdoor adventures, or simply sharing laughter at home. Having a mum who owns and builds indoor playgrounds, do your kids consider themselves the luckiest in Singapore? They certainly have fun testing new playground features and being the first customers at Kiztopia. But to them, I’m simply ‘mum.’ Their joy and excitement remind me daily why I started this journey—to create spaces where families can bond and children can flourish. Read more: Best Indoor Playgrounds In Singapore Image credit: Heidi Tian What are some things you hope your children learn from you when they grow up? I hope they develop resilience, a strong work ethic, and the courage to pursue their dreams. More than anything, I want them to understand the value of kindness, humility, and always staying grounded, no matter how successful they become. Throughout your journey of juggling entrepreneurship and motherhood, what are some surprising things you’ve learnt about yourself and parenthood? I’ve learned that I’m much stronger and more adaptable than I ever thought. Motherhood and entrepreneurship both require resilience, patience, and the ability to handle unpredictability. I’ve also realised the importance of embracing imperfection—there’s no perfect way to do either, and that’s okay. Running Kiztopia has given me a deeper appreciation for the way children learn and grow through play. One surprising insight is how differently every child engages with play—some seek adventure, others prefer quiet observation, and many thrive through social interaction. It has reinforced my belief that there’s no “one-size-fits-all” approach to parenting; instead, providing the right environment and opportunities for kids to explore at their own pace is key. Quickfire questions: I wish I had more time for… Unplugged family time—just being present without distractions. And maybe catching up on sleep! I always feel saner after… Enjoying a quiet coffee, taking a walk with my husband, or sharing meaningful conversations with my kids—simple moments that remind me of what truly matters. As a mama, I wish I were better at… Letting go of the small stuff and staying fully present. It’s easy to get caught up in work, but children grow up in the blink of an eye! I wake up in the middle of the night thinking about… New ideas for Kiztopia, upcoming projects, and how best to prepare my kids for the future. My favourite moment of the day is… Winding down with my family—whether over dinner or a casual chat. Those little moments mean everything. Read our past That Mama interviews here . The post Meet The Mum Of Two Behind Singapore’s Largest Indoor Playgrounds, Heidi Tian appeared first on Sassy Mama .

Students also enjoyed breathtaking hikes, bike rides, zip lining, waterfalls, and a visit to the Night Market. More importantly, students gain a deeper understanding of their role in healing the world. In Vietnam, students spent time at the Village of Hope, where they painted classrooms, planted gardens, and worked alongside local children and teachers to improve the school environment. It was a heartwarming exchange of cultures and kindness, made even more memorable by creating handmade gifts for the children they met. These overseas trips are a reflection of SMMIS values – teamwork, global citizenship, community responsibility, and service. For students who remain in Singapore, they take part in service-learning experiences. From sports to the arts, students engage in local initiatives that build leadership, empathy, and a strong sense of social responsibility. Alongside the launch of YEP, The Winstedt School has also updated its Vision, Mission, and Values to better reflect its inclusive approach and commitment to innovative education. The school’s new mission is to provide equity in education through innovative teaching and learning. Its vision is to create inclusive education for those who think and learn differently. Underpinning this are Winstedt’s refreshed values: Creativity – Thinking beyond the ordinary; Courage – Facing your challenges with purpose; Excellence – Being empowered learners who strive to do their best; Respect – Being kind while appreciating others’ values and beliefs; Resilience – Staying determined and strong through setbacks Enjoy a 50% early bird discount on enrolment fees for all Early Years programmes (Year 1, Year 2 and YEP) when you enrol by 1 June 2025! articles.title: 8 Best Places For Glamping In Singapore + NEW Colugo Camp At Mandai Wildlife East
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Have you tried glamping in Singapore? Whether you want to go outdoor glamping on the East Coast, Sentosa, Lazarus Island, indoor glamping or even glamping at the zoo, here’s our guide to glamping in Singapore with fairy lights, plush mattresses and even air-con! Glamping in Singapore is basically super posh camping! If you’re keen to take the kiddos camping but just can’t deal with setting your own tent up, or sleeping on a hard surface with no aircon, then you’ll want to try glamping! It combines the wonders of sleeping outside with the creature comforts of a chalet or hotel staycation . Glamping in Singapore is a unique way to spend the night outdoors, whether for a big birthday party , a romantic getaway, or good old-fashioned family bonding. Check out our roundup of all the best spots to take the kids glamping in Singapore! Read more: Best Kids’ Activities & Things To Do In Singapore What does it mean to go glamping? Glamping is a word blend of “glamorous” and “camping” — taking all the fun of camping in a tent but elevating the experience. It’s basically a more glamorous form of camping that includes already set up tents, often proper beds or plush mattresses, electricity (and sometimes air-con!), cushions, picnic tables and at one glamping spot a BBQ or pizza offer! How is glamping different to camping? Glamping is definitely a more comfortable experience! But if you’re keen to teach the kids how to set up a tent, make your own food on a campfire, and rough it for the night, glamping won’t quite cut it. You’ll defo get a better night’s sleep glamping though! As with proper camping, when you go glamping in Singapore you’ll still need to apply for an NParks camping permit for free . How much is glamping in Singapore? Glamping in Singapore is not as cheap as camping but more affordable than a hotel stay. The cheapest outdoor glamping we found is from $210 per night for 2 pax, and the most expensive glamping at Singapore Zoo is a whopping $1,699 per tent! Read more: Pulau Ubin Camping Trip with Kids! Best Places for Glamping in Singapore: Ready to go glamping in Singapore? These glamping providers offer glamping in East Coast Park , Pasir Ris Park (home to one of our very fave playgrounds in Singapore !), Sentosa , Singapore Zoo, Lazarus Island , and during certain times of the year, indoor glamping at Jewel! Plus, we found some glamping options for the kids to enjoy in the comfort of your own home! 1. Colugo Camp: Glamping at Mandai Wildlife Reserve Image credit: Mandai Wildlife Group There’s a brand-new glamping experience at Mandai Wildllife Reserve, opening in Q3 2025! Colugo Camp puts you right near all the action at the Singapore Zoo , the new Rainforest Wild Asia and all of the fab wildlife parks in the area. This glamping experience in Singapore is drizzled with convenience and luxury. Colugo Camp is an all-inclusive experience, meaning that everything, including accommodation, dining, guided tours and wildlife encounters, is included in your stay! Best of all, Colugo Camp will be a permanent site with 20 safari tents, so you can get closer to nature year-round. Glamping location: Mandai Wildlife East Glamping rates: TBA – opening in Q3 2025. Colugo Camp, Mandai Wildlife EAST 80 Mandai Lake Road Singapore 729826, www.mandai.com 2. Glamping City Singapore Image credit: Glamping City Singapore via Facebook Glamping City Singapore offers chic glamping tents in the vibrant East Coast Park. Whether you are organising a glamping trip for a birthday celebration or a romantic evening, Glamping City Singapore has something for every occasion. Glamping City also has a movie screening add-on, where you can view movies in the comfort of your spacious tents or under the stars. Looking to organise a kids’ birthday party sleepover in your backyard or living room? You can also book the slumber party package for indoor glamping or backyard glamping fun. Glamping locations: East Coast Park Glamping rates: From $219 per night for the Couple Deluxe (Sea View) Package Glamping City Singapore, 1500 East Coast Park, Singapore 468963, Tel: (+65) 9830 3090, www.glampingcity.com 3. Glamping Society Image credit: Glamping Society Singapore’s first glamping provider, Glamping Society offers glamping tent packages in both East Coast Park and Pasir Ris Seaside. They offer simple couple glamping staycations (with fairy lights, a candlelit picnic , and a pizza) to a glamorous proposal package or a birthday celebration glamping package. Pasir Ris Seaside glamping tents are air-conditioned, and glam tents are kitted out with beds, rugs and colourful cushions. We think the Glam Birthday Party Package (including pizzas, balloons, birthday cake, an outdoor cinema and a float for up to 6 people), would be a big hit for a kid’s birthday party . Glamping locations: East Coast Park (Area G/D) and Pasir Ris Seaside Glamping. Glamping rates: From $299 per night, which includes a picnic set-up, drinks and pizza. Guests are required to secure their own camping permit for East Coast Park. Camping permits are not required for Pasir Ris Seaside glamping. Glamping Society , 1500 East Coast Park, Singapore 468963, Tel: (+65) 9040 1817, www.glampingsociety.com 4. Go Glamping SG Image credit: Go Glamping SG Looking for a staycation near East Coast Park but hoping for something more affordable than a hotel or chalet ? Go Glamping SG rents out fully-equipped waterproof bell glamping tents complete with air beds, comfy indoor and outdoor seating, and beautiful lights. Go Glamping SG also provides a BBQ starter bundle at $52 and the BBQ food (for 5 pax) at an additional $52. If you’re feeling extra hungry, opt for the additional Premium package, which comes with Satay and Otah! Glamping locations: East Coast Park (Area G) Glamping rates: $320 per night for Family Tent. Guests are required to secure their own camping permit. Go Glamping SG , Tel: (+65) 9179 0416 (WhatsApp only) www.goglampingsg.com 5. Glamping Kaki Singapore Image Credit: Glamping Kaki Looking for an affordable glamping experience in Singapore? Glamping Kaki Singapore has you covered! Located at East Coast Park , this glamping experience will allow you to escape from the hectic city life and return to nature for a relaxing getaway. Bell Glamping tents are available in three different sizes and come with queen sized beds as well as fairy lights. Enhance your experience by booking the outdoor glam picnic table add-on for $70 (for 6 pax)! Glamping location: East Coast Park Glamping rates : From $210 per night for 2 pax; the Superior Large Tent (sleeping 6 pax) is $290. Guests are required to secure their own camping permit for East Coast Park. Glamping Kaki, 1500 East Coast Park, Singapore 468963, Tel: (+65) 8431 9137, www. glampingkaki.com 6. Heavenly Glamping Singapore Image credit: Heavenly Glamping Singapore Heavenly Glamping Singapore offers luxurious glamping that will have you feeling like royalty. Expect a spacious, beautifully decorated tent with a cosy set-up for you and your special someone. If you have a larger group, check out the Grand Deluxe Glamping Tent for six with three queen-size air beds, a BBQ pit, a large gazebo, fairy lights and more. You can book glamping experiences at East Coast Park and Heritage Chalet at Pasir Ris, with tents for two, four and six people. Be sure to check out their glamping add-ons from birthday celebration packages (+ $60)! You can even book a super fancy glamping picnic at East Coast Park, Fort Canning or at Gardens by the Bay East from $180 (3.5 hours). Glamping locations: East Coast Park and Heritage Chalet at Pasir Ris Glamping rates: From $240 per night for Deluxe Package for 4 pax. Guests are required to secure their own camping permit for East Coast Park. Heavenly Glamping, www.heavenlyglamping.com 7. Kids’ Indoor Glamping Image credit: Estilo & Co Have you ever considered indoor glamping for a fun kids’ birthday celebration ? From setting up boho floral teepees to creating a Star Wars-themed glamping sleepover with iconic Star Wars cushions and light sabres, an indoor glamping experience is an exciting way to throw a birthday celebration! These cute glamping teepees make great photo ops, and the kids are sure to have a blast having a sleepover with their friends. If you want to give your child’s bedroom a magical makeover for their birthday bash, check out Estilo & Co! You can choose from a range of enchanting themes, such as the whimsical fairy forest theme! Glamping location: Your living room! Glamping prices: from $490 for 3 tents. Estilo & Co, www.estiloandco.com 8. Glamping at Lazarus Island Image credit: Into The Woods Into The Woods is an exciting new glamping experience on the serene Lazarus Island in Singapore, serving as a perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of the Lion City. There are 9 glamping units, including 3 family accommodations spanning 36 sqm that can accommodate up to 4 people. Each unit is equipped with air-conditioning, and guests will receive a welcoming kit filled with eco-friendly products from local businesses. While the grown-ups indulge in rejuvenating yoga sessions, the little ones will be enchanted by the watercolour painting sets, all part of Into The Woods’ commitment to promoting slow living and ensuring guests enjoy low-intensity activities during their stay. Glamping location: 15A Pulau Seringat, Lazarus Island, Singapore 099551 Glamping prices: from $430 per night for Family Tent Into the Woods, intothewoods.life Glamping experiences in Singapore that have since closed: Indoor Glamping at Jewel Changi Airport (Closed) Image credit: Cherilyn Gan Ever dreamed of falling asleep to the sound of Jewel’s magnificent waterfall? During certain times of the year, you can go indoor glamping at Jewel Changi Airport. While you don’t get a glamorous tent with fairy lights, you’ll get a spacious camping tent from Decathlon that sleeps up to three people, a fun itinerary with exciting family-bonding activities and access to the Changi Experience Studio. Our glamping experience included rock climbing at Climb@T3 , a family quest through the mall, and a craft workshop for the kids. Meals are not included, though, so be sure to find the best spots for food at Jewel here . We’d recommend this indoor camping experience for families with kids between 7 to 13 years old. Read all about our experience at Jewel here! Glamping location: Jewel Changi Airport Glamping prices: $85 (adult) & $95 (child – 5 years and up). Do note that this is only available for limited times during the year. Be sure to check back here for their upcoming dates! (Closed) Changi Experience Studio, Jewel Changi Airport, 21 Airport Boulevard, Singapore 819666, www.changiairport.com Read more: The Best Spots for Glamping in Asia and Australia Glamping at Singapore Zoo (Closed) Image credit: Mandai Wildlife Group Fancy spending the night with Asian elephants, white tigers and rhinos? For limited periods each year, you can book a glamping staycation at Singapore Zoo . Keep an eye out on their website for the next glamping period. This glamping experience in Singapore includes a night’s stay in an air-conditioned dome glamping tent at the Pavilion by the Lake for up to four people. This glamping option is far more expensive than any other glamping tent rentals in Singapore, but here you’ll get dinner and breakfast thrown in, along with park admission to Singapore Zoo, guided animal tours and animal encounters. Do note that kids must be at least 5 years old to join in the glamping fun. Glamping location: Singapore Zoo Glamping rates: From $1,699 per tent, up to 4 pax (U.P. $2,000) Singapore Zoo, 80 Mandai Lake Rd, 729826, www.mandai.com Wondrous Glamping Singapore (Temporarily Closed) Image Credit: Wondrous Glamping Singapore With plots in East Coast Park , Wondrous Glamping Singapore offers a unique seaside glamping experience, combining a cosy glamping tent with a rare opportunity for stargazing. Bell glamping tents come with a queen-size air mattress and bed, bed linens, pillows, and stylish touches like rugs and fairy lights. We love that they even provide a board game as a standard amenity with each glamping tent! They also do specially tailored packages for birthday celebrations , anniversaries and more. If you don’t want to spend the night there, you can book a glamping picnic package in their glamping tents for $250 for five hours. Be sure to book your glamping tent rental slot ahead as Wondrous Glamping Singapore is only open for bookings from Thursdays to Sundays. Guests are required to secure their own camping permit for East Coast Park. articles.content: Get ready for Gardens by the Bay’s Children’s Festival (24 May to 15 June 2025) featuring Disney’s Stitch! Read on to find out what’s in store for kids. Looking for things to do during the June school holidays ? Children’s Festival at Gardens by the Bay is back from 24 May to 15 June 2025, with large-scale Stitch-themed installations play areas and fun activities. Just in time for the release of Disney’s Lilo & Stitch, which opens in cinemas on 22 May. Children can explore the value of friendship and family as they discover how to appreciate and accept themselves just as they are. Full details have yet to be released, but where’s what you can expect at Children’s Festival 2025 at Gardens by the Bay. Children’s Festival 2025 Gardens by the Bay’s signature Children’s Festival is an annual kids’ event that takes place during the mid-year school holidays . This year marks its 11th edition, and Stitch from Disney’s Lilo & Stitch is the main character for this outdoor carnival for the first time ever. Families can snap tonnes of photos with large-scale installations and most of the activities are free! Read more: June School Holiday Camps Large-scale installations at Children’s Festival 2025 (FREE!) Full details of the installations have yet to be released, but here are some to look forward to at Children’s Festival 2025. The Great ‘Ohana Wave: A nearly 7-metre-tall slide for adventurous kiddos to “surf” down from the top, giving them a confidence boost! Forest of Belonging: An inflatable forest where visitors can uncover hidden messages. Space Adventure: Hop onboard a swing car to power up light beams and complete missions. articles.title: i Light Singapore 2025: IG-worthy Interactive Piano Walk, Flower Meadow & More
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: i Light Singapore 2025 (29 May – 21 June 2025) returns to Marina Bay and neighbouring precincts and features IG-worthy interactive art and multi-sensory light experiences! Read on for what to expect. The highly anticipated annual event, i Light Singapore 2025, is back at Marina Bay, South Beach, Raffles Place, the Singapore River and more, from 29 May – 21 June 2025. This SG60 edition is specially designed around the theme of To Gather and features the colour red, in celebration of SG60. 17 new light installations and an array of activities will aim to unite people from all backgrounds and generate conversations for a more sustainable future through eco-friendly habits . Like its previous editions, you can expect plenty of creative artwork, exciting programmes and dazzling light displays. i Light Singapore 2025 highlights 1. Illuminated garden with 300 flowers Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 The name Take a walk through the meadow with me speaks for itself. This i Light Singapore 2025 art installation by Singapore artists Megan Tan and Shao Xuan features over 300 illuminated flowers, all made from acrylic waste from fabrication studios and workshops. Take your time to explore this whimsical meadow; we hear the flowers will even say “hello” with light and music! Location: The Lawn beside the NTUC Building 2. Piano Walk, where you can make music Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 Another interactive light installation at i Light Singapore 2025 is the Piano Walk by Amigo & Amigo from Australia. Step on the piano keys and get as creative as you like. The installation will automatically play an original composition every 10 minutes, based on all your steps! Location: Event Plaza by the Marina Bay waterfront 3. Elementary: An interactive screen Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 This one’s sure to be a hit with the little ones. Elementary by Tonoptik from Montenegro may look like a normal flat screen. But move around in front of it and observe how your movements transform the virtual landscape of the screen. It’s inspired by the ocean and represents the human relationship with the unpredictable rhythm of nature. Pretty deep! Location: Clifford Square (next to Fullerton Bay Hotel) 4. Urban Oracle: Light reflections on water Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 This one’s a really cool use of AI. Urban Oracle by Italy artist Ultravioletto uses the reflection of the water to highlight AI-generated messages from 24 illuminated letters. Press one of the three buttons along the boardwalk to find messages inspired by the past, present and future of Singapore’s past. Location: Pontoon near Red Dot Design Museum 5. Reverse Waterfall: Gravity-defying water Image credit: Nicole Ang This one doesn’t need much explanation, but is definitely worth a look. After all, it is a waterfall flowing in the reverse direction! Take time to observe it; the artist UxU Studio from Taiwan (presented by UOB) intend for festival-goers to reflect on what really is “natural”? Location: UOB Plaza, by the Singapore River 6. Bridge of 1,000 Dreams: Illuminated bamboo sticks Image credit: Nicole Ang Also presented by UOB and DesignSingapore Council, the Bridge of 1,000 Dreams transforms the Cavenagh Bridge into a feast for the eyes with bamboo sticks illuminating it. It’s meant to represent how Singaporeans dream of a future that’s stronger. Location: Cavenagh Bridge along the Singapore River 7. The Guardians: Inflatable garden Image credit: Nicole Ang Another one the kids will love! The Guardians is an inflatable garden that’s incredibly Instagrammable. Australian artists Matthew Aberline and The Beautiful and Useful Studio are putting Singapore’s amazing flora on display, and this one’s certainly a show-stopper. Location: Raffles Place Park 8. Saulux: Light installation with sound Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 Saulux isn’t just any ol’ light installation; it creates an “auditory experience” with the wind transforming willow twigs into light and sound. So, be sure to listen out for the magic when you encounter this installation by SPACES.STUDIO from Malta. Location: Fountain Plaza, South Beach 9. This is Not a Screen: Made from digital waste Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 This is Not a Screen invites visitors to ponder how digital technology can present different realities to each individual. Is what we see a shared perception? Take a moment to reflect on all that at this installation made from recycled electronic waste. Location: Near South Beach’s entrance to the Esplanade MRT station 10. Fantastic Planet: Larger-than-life humanoid figures Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 This one’s probably the highlight of i Light Singapore 2025, because Fantastic Planets features towering humanoid figures that you can easily spot from a mile away. This installation by Amanda Parer aims to reframe one’s perception of scale and space, inviting visitors to think deeper about humanity’s place in the universe and our impact on the planet. Location: Along Marina Bay waterfront 11. Sign: Campfire-like installation Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 Sign is an artwork installation by Vendel & de wolf that features a supersize “campfire” that is actually an illusion of flames. Visitors are encouraged to pause and witness the unique spectacle of fire catching light around it, invoking thoughts of igniting radical change through destruction. Location: Near The Promontory 11. In Tandem: Immersive installation by students from NUS Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 In Tandem, created by Nanyang Technological University students Lee Si Heidi, Rae Koh, and Leela Rao (Singapore), uses biometric sensors to transform visitors’ heartbeats into synchronised light and sound patterns displayed on a glowing sphere. Location: Near The Promontory 12. Mozart: Deconstructed piano Image credit: i Light Singapore 2025 Located along the steps of The Helix Bridge, Mozart features a glowing white sphere symbolising a deconstructed piano. This interactive light installation comes alive with every footstep, generating compositions that mirror its fragmented form. Festival-goers are invited to step into the role of performer in this vibrant reimagining of classical music that highlights how disruption can spark new forms of creativity. Location: Helix Bridge i Light Singapore 2025 Programme Apart from the artworks and light displays, i Light Singapore 2025 will also feature a range of complementary activities and programmes. GastoBeats: Gastronomic delights & musical experiences Image credit: Aisyah Amin – Last year’s GastroBeats Festival Village Get ready for GastroBeats , the Festival Village of i Light Singapore 2025, where you’ll be spoiled for choice with a variety of gastronomic delights as you bask in impressive musical experiences. Check out the pet-friendly zones and retail booths, and keep an eye out for Let’s Trouble The Water! , where visitors can take a stand against marine pollution. Where: Bayfront Event Space When: 29 May – 22 June 2025, 4pm – 11pm Daily How much: General admission to the Festival Village is free, but charges apply for selected activities. Campfyre @ Nomads Pop-Up: Lounge in camping chairs Image credit: Unsplash – for illustrative purposes only. Bask in the electric atmosphere of i Light Singapore 2025 and unwind in camping chairs under the glow of the light art installation Sign . Pick up some light bites and drinks from GastroBeats, and enjoy a magical night of connection and conversation with friends and family at Campfyre . Where: The Promontory at Marina Bay When: 29 May – 1 June, 6 – 8 June, 13 – 15 June, 20 and 21 June 2025 How much: General admission is free, but charges apply for food and beverage. Silent Disco Parade: Join an open-air dance party Image credit: i Light Singapore 2024 Put on wireless headphones playing feel-good music and join a giant dance procession through the heart of Marina Bay. This immersive route will take you through i Light Singapore’s breathtaking art installations against the backdrop of Singapore’s magical nightscapes. Where: Marina Bay (meeting point is outside ArtScience Museum) When: 20 June 2025, 7:30pm – 9:30pm How much: $35. Register here. i Light River Cruise Shuttle Service: Magical boat ride Image credit: i Light Singapore Hop into a river cruise that will take you through Marina Bay and Singapore River so you can marvel at the illuminated artwork from a different perspective. Be sure to get your cameras ready, because there will be plenty of picturesque, IG-worthy moments along the way. More info here. Where: Bayfront South Jetty, Clifford Pier Jetty and Raffles Place Jetty When: 29 May to 1 June, 6 to 8 June, 13 June, 15 and 20 June 2025 How much: $6 – $18 Glow PAddle 2025: LED-illuminated dragon boat Image credit: i Light Singapore Join an enchanting night expedition across Marina Bay as you paddle away on LED-illuminated dragon boats. Beyond sightseeing, this is a unique opportunity to discover a blend of culture and community spirit as you join other paddlers. Learn from certified dragon boat trainers and discover fascinating stories about Singapore’s iconic landmarks. Where: PAssion Wave @ Marina Bay, 11 Rhu Cross, Singapore 437440 When: 8 and 15 June 2025 How much: $30 per PAssion card member and $45 per non-PAssion card member. Get tickets for 8 June here and 15 June here . Sunset Silent Flow: 90-minute yoga at The Promontory Image credit: i Light Singapore Let your stress melt away as you join Sunset Silent Flow, a 90-minute yoga session against the iconic skyline at The Promontory. You will get to put on a wireless headset so you can tune out the buzz of the city and move with every beat of the music. Where: The Promontory at Marina Bay When: 21 June 2025, 7pm – 8:30pm How much: $42 per pax or two Yoga Movement credits. Register your interest here. A Meadow Memory Workshop: Create a personalised charm Image credit: i Light Singapore Get creative at a sustainable workshop, where you will create a unique keychain while reflecting on sustainability and upcycling. Discover how commonly discarded materials can be repurposed to create gorgeous pieces with thoughtful design. Where: Lawn beside NTUC Building When: 31 May 2025 and 7 June 2025, 6pm & 7:30pm How much: $3 per pax. Register your interest here. i Light Singapore 2025 dates, tickets & more When: 29 May – 21 June 2025, 7:30pm – 11pm daily with extended hours to midnight on Fridays and Saturdays Price: Admission is FREE, but certain programmes will have separate charges. Where : Marina Bay, South Beach, Raffles Place and Singapore River i Light Singapore 2025 , www.ilightsingapore.gov.sg Discover more fun things to do with kids in Singapore! articles.title: Guide To Baby Classes & Playgroups In Singapore
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Looking for a bilingual playgroup, drop-off playgroup or parent-accompanied playgroup near you? Take your bub to one of these organised baby playgroups so your baby can learn and explore while you meet other parents! Whether you want to spend some quality time with your baby, meet other parents with similar-aged bubs or want to start their education at a young age, checking out a baby playgroup in Singapore is your best bet. While the newborn phase can definitely feel like a bit of a sleep-deprived blur at times, soon enough, you’ll be itching to get out of the house and do something more than just stare at your adorable munchkin on a play mat. From music and movement baby classes (even newborns like listening to songs!) to swimming and messy play, there are heaps of playgroups out there to stimulate babies – not exactly enrichment classes , but bubs will develop in leaps and bounds in a nurturing, age-appropriate manner. We’ve included parent- and caretaker-accompanied baby playgroups, as well as drop-off infant care facilities for working parents to cover the full range of possibilities out there! Kim Paradise , www.kimparadise.com.sg Read more: Must-Try Chinese Restaurants In Singapore Le Xin Catering: Convenient tingkat delivery Image credit: Le Xin Catering Group via Facebook Le Xin Catering offers tasty tingkat meals for lunch and dinner, depending on your family’s needs. Le Xin Catering , www.lexincatering.com.sg Neo Garden: Tingkat meals with international cuisines Image credit: Neo Garden Do you crave a different cuisine once a week? Offering international cuisines from Korea, Japan, and Thailand, Neo Garden includes dishes like Bibimbap, Thai Style Green Curry Chicken and more to spice up the menu. Neo Garden is a popular caterer in Singapore that offers an omakase tingkat plan for big families, as well as buffet and event menus for special occasions. Tingkat delivery prices: From $7.25 per person for the Family Omakase daily meals with a minimum 10-day subscription. Neo Garden, www.neogarden.com.sg Savoury Catering: Healthy tingkat delivery Image credit: Savoury Catering via Facebook Savoury Catering prides itself on serving only quality, nutritious food. Tingkat delivery prices: From $5.50+ per person per day Select Catering , www.selectcatering.com.sg Shiok Kitchen Catering: Halal tingkat delivery Image credit: Shiok Kitchen Catering Shiok Kitchen Catering offers a Shiok Healthy Tingkat. articles.title: Best Nail Salons In Singapore For Your Much-Needed Mani-Pedi, Nail Art & Gelish Manicures

articles.content: Keen to get your nails done? We round up the best nail salons in Singapore that offer express gel manicures, classic pedicures, nail art and more. Looking for a nail salon in Singapore to give your nails a fresh look? We’ve got you covered. Whether you’re looking to do a classic manicure, a Gelish manicure or need to give your feet some tender loving care with a pedicure, you’ll be sure to find a nail salon near you with our list of the best nail salons in Singapore! So, take this as your sign to make an appointment at one of these nail salons and treat yourself for tirelessly taking care of your family. You deserve it, mama! Read more: Mobile Beauty Services In Singapore That Come To Your Home Best Nail Salons In Singapore: 1. Nail Palace: Popular nail salon with 20+ outlets Image credit: Nail Palace Nail Palace is one of the most popular nail salons in Singapore, thanks to their creative and gorgeous nail art and mani-pedis. Whether you’re in a pinch and need an express gel manicure or would like to indulge in a deluxe pedicure, Nail Palace has what you need. They also offer a variety of treatments, including sole renewal treatment and corn treatment, plus hair removal and eyelash services. Nail Palace, multiple locations in Singapore including Ang Mo Kio, Bugis and Bukit Panjang, www.nailpalace.com.sg 2. Pixie Nail Spa: Comfy nail salon with friendly staff Image credit: Pixie Nail Spa Pixie Nail Spa has 15 outlets across Singapore, so this is another popular nail salon that you can easily find near you. Their nail salons have super comfy seats that will make you feel like a queen, while their expert manicurist turns your dream nails into a reality. Opt for a classic manicure or a Gelish manicure for something more durable. They also offer lash extensions and brow embroidery services. Pixie Nail Spa, multiple locations in Singapore including Orchard, Tampines and Yishun, www.pixienailspagroup.com 3. N20 Nail Spa: Award-winning nail salon Image credit: N20 Nail Spa Looking for a nail salon in Singapore with a track record of satisfied customers? N20 Nail Spa has been voted the “Best Spa Manicure” and “Best Nail Salon Services”. They use high-quality, dermatologist-certified nail polish from brands including Chanel, Morgan Taylor and Orly. Their long-lasting nail polishes produce gorgeous colours that are resistant to chipping and smudging. N20 Nail Spa, seven locations in Singapore including Jurong East, Sengkang and Dhoby Ghaut, www.n20.com.sg 4. Maco Nail Spa: Gel manicure & nail extensions Image credit: Maco Nail Spa Managed by Pixie Nail Spa, you can rest assured that you will get quality manicure and pedicure services at Maco Nail Spa. Conveniently located at Holland Village, you can easily pop by during a lunch break to treat yourself to a mani-pedi. They offer classic manicures, gel manicures, acrylic nails, hybrid nails and gel nail extensions and more. Maco Nail Spa, 200 Holland Avenue, #B1-01, Singapore 278995, www.pixienailspagroup.com 5. Nail Addiction: Nail salon with affordable manicure Image credit: Nail Addiction Nail Addiction is more than just a nail salon in Singapore. In addition to an affordable express manicure, this nail salon also offers massages, foot reflexology and ear candling. If you want to treat yourself, try their manicure spa, pedicure spa or top-up for a nail mask treatment. Need to de-stress? You can also get a head massage here! Nail Addiction, multiple locations in Singapore including Temasek Boulevard, Ang Mo Kio and Kovan, www.nailaddiction.sg Read more: Best Spas In Singapore 6. Nailz Gallery: Affordable nail salon for a mani-pedi Image credit: Nailz Gallery Nailz Gallery is a nail salon you can’t miss when you walk past it in a mall. Known for their affordable nail services, Nailz Gallery is a top choice for a classic manicure and classic pedicure. They also offer Gelish manicures and other beauty services, including eyelash extensions and eyebrow embroidery. Nailz Gallery, multiple locations in Singapore including Jurong East, Woodlands and Raffles City, www.nailzgallery.com 7. The Nail Arcadia: Beauty salon for nails & lashes Image credit: The Nail Arcadia Looking for a fuss-free nail salon in Singapore?
