articles.title: Students Get Into Their Choice Universities Thanks To This School’s AP Programme (+ $500 Off!)
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Looking to give your teen a head start in university? Learn how the Advanced Placement (AP) Programme can set them up for academic success to thrive in university and beyond. Applying to international universities can be highly competitive, and giving your child a strong academic foundation could be the key to standing out. If you’ve been wondering how to help your child stand out, the AP Programme might be just what they need! But what exactly is the AP Programme, and how does it compare to options like the IB? We break down what the AP Programme is all about, and how International Community School’s (ICS) AP Programme equips students with the critical thinking, time management, and academic confidence they need to shine in competitive international applications. Is the AP Programme a better fit for my child? Got a teen excelling in certain subjects and eager to explore them further? The AP Programme offers the perfect opportunity! Students can choose courses that align with their interests and goals, challenging themselves while developing critical thinking skills. Students also get to earn college credits along the way, giving them a head start in their university journey while saving both time and money on their degree. Although the courses in the AP Programme are more college-level compared to those in the IB Programme , the amount of credit awarded varies by university and course. On the other hand, students in the more holistic IB Programme are awarded credits for high scores in Higher Level (HL) exams, with the threshold often set at a score of 5 or higher. The AP Programme is subject-specific, allowing students to choose individual courses and earn credits based on the number of AP exams taken and their scores. The AP Programme gives students more flexibility, allowing them to focus on subjects they’re interested in or need for specific university requirements, giving them a smoother transition into university life. Plus, AP courses are designed to match college-level content, pace, and exams, helping students prep for what’s ahead. How the AP Programme at ICS sets students up for success At ICS, students can choose from over 20 AP courses across STEM, business, humanities, and the arts. To keep students on track, teachers assign summer work to kickstart the year and use tools like the College Board’s AP Classroom, progress checks, and past exam questions. Regular feedback, small group sessions, and extra support during lunch or after school are also part of the well-rounded approach that ICS takes to ensure students stay ahead. At ICS, AP students have achieved an impressive average score of 4.2 out of 5, earning placements in top universities worldwide, including those in the U.S., U.K., Canada, Europe, and Australia! Courses here challenge students to analyse, synthesise, and communicate complex ideas and then nurture them into independent learners and effective time managers. Some of the high-achieving courses at ICS, known for strong performance both in exam results and student engagement, include AP Psychology, AP Calculus, and AP English Literature. Students also receive personalised guidance from counsellors to help them choose the right courses that align with their academic goals. Curious if ICS is the right fit for your child? Join their upcoming virtual open house to find out more! Join ICS’s Virtual Open Houses to enjoy a $500 waiver on your application fee! International Community School (ICS) , 27a Jubilee Road, Singapore 128575, www.ics.edu.sg The post Students Get Into Their Choice Universities Thanks To This School’s AP Programme (+ $500 Off!) appeared first on Sassy Mama .

articles.title: You Can Now Easily Get High-Quality & Nutritious Ingredients From New Zealand Right Here In SG
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Get ready to ‘Discover A Taste of New Zealand’ because Cold Storage and CS Fresh are bringing the best of Kiwi goodness to Singapore with premium food, live performances and more. As parents, making sure our kids are fed is one thing, but making sure they eat a nutritious, well-balanced meal is another. If you’re searching for something you can feel good about feeding your family, you’re in luck, because the New Zealand Trade and Enterprise is partnering up with Cold Storage for a campaign where you can experience premium New Zealand products right here in Singapore! New Zealand Premium Food and Beverage So, what makes New Zealand produce so special? New Zealand is known for its ethical farming practices that prioritise quality, safety, and sustainability, making sure that every bite is as good as nature intended. These ethical farming practices go hand in hand with New Zealand’s natural advantages such as clean air, lush pastures, fertile soils, and crystal-clear waters – all of which create the perfect conditions for nutritious, delicious food. It’s no wonder New Zealand produce consistently wins international awards! From free-range poultry, grass-fed beef and lamb to GMO-free fruits, natural manuka honey, premium dairy and indulgent snacks, New Zealand offers food that’s healthier, fresher, and ethically sourced, and are guaranteed to impress the pickiest little eaters in the family! ‘Discover A Taste of New Zealand’ in Singapore If you’re keen to stock up your pantry with premium New Zealand products, head down to Cold Storage and CS Fresh stores islandwide to experience the best of New Zealand firsthand and learn more about where your food comes from! The three-week campaign (17 April to 7 May 2025) will run across 35 outlets, featuring well-loved New Zealand brands such as Anchor, Cookie Time , Meadow Fresh , Mother Earth , Otis , Rockit Apple , Tegel , Whittaker’s , Zespri , Zeagold and more. That’s not all, you can also shop from other well-loved New Zealand brands such as Comvita , Nice & Natural , Fourflax and K9 Natural , at Comvita x HoneyWorld stores, Lazada , Ace Asia Pet Care , and Kohepets respectively. The highly anticipated campaign kicked off with a launch event at Cold Storage Great World City last week, featuring special live cultural performances including a Kapa Haka and Waiata showcase by students from the Australian International School. If you missed the performances, not to worry—mark your calendars and head down to Cold Storage and CS Fresh to discover what makes New Zealand food so special! Made with Care: New Zealand food is safe, tasty, of premium quality, nutritious and ethical. ‘Discover A Taste of New Zealand’ fair, Cold Storage and CS Fresh stores islandwide, www.facebook.com/DiscoverNew.NZ.SG The post You Can Now Easily Get High-Quality & Nutritious Ingredients From New Zealand Right Here In SG appeared first on Sassy Mama .

articles.title: Celebrate Helper Appreciation Month In May
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: We encourage families to think of ways, big and small, to say thank you to your helper this May during Helper Appreciation Month. May is Helper Appreciation Month in Singapore. This celebration of helpers in Singapore is something we at Sassy Mama fully support. The idea for celebrating helpers throughout the month of May began in Hong Kong, where resident Steve Chitty pointed out the month is a natural fit given that it encompasses Labour Day, Mother’s Day and the International Day of Families. Since we began with a one-day celebration and awards ceremony in 2016 to say thank you to helpers and recognise all the amazing ways they support our families, the celebration evolved from large events to show helpers how much we appreciate them to small gestures like holding giveaways. Here’s how we began to celebrate and recognise helpers’ crucial contributions to our families, plus scroll for lots of helpful resources for your helper, from further education opportunities to Gift Ideas to show your gratitude and appreciation for all your helper’s hard work. Helper Appreciation May Education is key to ensuring helpers break the cycle of poverty. articles.title: Family-Friendly Rock Climbing & Bouldering Gyms In Singapore
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Check out these kid-friendly places for rock climbing and bouldering in Singapore. Want to take the kids rock climbing or bouldering in Singapore? Rock climbing is such a fun physical family-friendly activity and it’s a great way for kids to develop gross motor skills and build stamina. Need a few recommendations for bouldering (which is a form of climbing without ropes) or kids’ rock climbing? We round up a few cool spots with themed climbing walls, augmented reality areas and more! Loads of these rock climbing and bouldering gyms are also open for younger kiddos – some even host birthday parties . All you have to do is come in sportswear and bring covered sports shoes with socks. You can rent special climbing shoes if needed, along with any other necessary equipment, from the rock climbing or bouldering gyms directly. Do note that you’ll need to check minimum age/weight requirement,s and you have to factor in rental on top of rock climbing entry fees. Keep scrolling to find out all the best rock climbing and bouldering gyms in Singapore! Difference between Bouldering and Rock Climbing: Bouldering is a type of rock climbing that doesn’t require a rope or harness. Bouldering walls are thus not very high since you only climb 3-5 metres. There will usually be a soft landing pad under a bouldering wall for you to land on if you fall. You’ll need to learn the correct bouldering techniques and how to return to the floor safely. Rock climbing (also called rope climbing) requires a rope and harness, and you frequently climb more than 9 metres off the ground. With rock climbing, many centres use an auto belay – an automatic electro-mechanical or mechanical climbing belay system. It replaces the need for someone to hold your rope and tighten it as you climb, as the auto-belay automatically retracts the climbing rope, taking up the slack as you climb. Kids can easily learn how to do this, but for safety, you should check that new climbers are locked in every time they climb. With bouldering, no such equipment is needed. Our kids have found rock climbing more fun as many of the climbing walls are themed, and they like the challenge of climbing high, which you don’t get with bouldering. Also, with bouldering, to come down from your climb, you need to jump to the crash pad. With rock climbing, kids get to rappel (abseil) back down safely with the auto-belay system, which is pretty fun! Read more: Where to Go for Kids’ Gymnastics Classes Best Rock Climbing & Bouldering Gyms in Singapore: 1. Ark Bloc: Bouldering Gym Image credit: Ark Bloc bouldering gym Ark Bloc in Punggol Container Park is a huge bouldering gym and fitness space for strength training and callisthenics. The bouldering gym is open to kids aged 5 and above with an accompanying adult. Over here, you can solve an array of bouldering challenges! Ark Bloc Punggol prices: From $28 for a full day pass. Ark Bloc, Punggol East Container Park, 6 Tebing Lane, #01-05, Singapore 828835, arkbloc.com 2. Outpost Climbing: Rock Climbing & Bouldering Image credit: T-Hall Outpost Climbing (previously called T-Hall) is a family-friendly indoor rock climbing and bouldering gym in Singapore with two zones. It’s probably our favourite rock-climbing spot in Singapore. Start at the Fun Zone if you are new to rock climbing or have kids. This rock climbing area has a cutting-edge augmented climbing wall, which uses motion-sensing tech to transform into various games where you’ll climb up, down and even sideways. There are fun-themed rock climbing walls that kids will love, from a Lego Wall to a Rubik’s Cube wall and even a glow-in-the-dark wall inside a dark tunnel! Kids as young as 4 years old (with a minimum weight of 15 kgs) can learn to climb her,e and you’ll get a safety briefing to learn how to use the auto-belay system before you can proceed to the rock climbing walls. The Climb Zone in a separate room is its own rock climbing and bouldering centre in itself! This huge rock climbing and bouldering space (the biggest we have seen in Singapore) lets you build your bouldering techniques, and also offers various certification programmes. Outpost Climbing rock climbing prices: Entry to the Fun Zone is from $28 (with a $10 add-on for accompanying non-climbing adults), and this includes rock climbing equipment. The Climb Zone rates start from $18 for youths & $28 for adults with rock climbing equipment rental on top. Outpost Climbing (previously T-Hall) , 464 Crawford Lane, Singapore 190464, www.outpostclimbing.sg 3. Climb@T3: Bouldering & Rock Climbing Image credit: Climb@T3 Climb@T3 is a new sport climbing attraction in Changi Airport! Managed by The Rock School Singapore, the indoor rock climbing wall features an 8m-tall High Wall (spanning Basements 2 and 3!) and a 12m-long bouldering wall. Fun fact: the climbing wall was constructed by the official wall provider for the 2020 and 2024 Olympic Games! The 2.5-metre-high Boulder Wall is best for younger and budding boulderers before they move on to the High Wall. There’s even a programme called The Rock Tots, designed for children aged two to six, filled with rock climbing and bouldering activities and games aimed at helping children get comfortable with bouldering! Rock climbing prices: From $19 for unguided sessions & from $38 for guided sessions. Climb@T3, Changi Airport Terminal 3,#B3-01/02, Singapore 819663, www.climbt3.sg 4. Adventure HQ: Bouldering & Rock Climbing Adventure HQ at HomeTeamNS Khatib is an indoor playground that’s actually geared for teens and adults, too! Expect themed indoor rock climbing walls, a bouldering wall, a ninja course, rope climbing structures and the longest indoor slide in Singapore! Adventure HQ at HomeTeamNS Khatib is open-air (but sheltered), so it gets hot and humid (dress in light sports gear). There is a section for bouldering and rock climbing with a range of walls with varying difficulty levels. With 8 climbing lanes, from Classic Top Rope or Automated Belaying climbing plus 24 interactive climbing elements. Children must be at least 1.25 m tall to climb. Rock climbing prices: If you wish to access only the Boulder + Rock Climb & Urban Climb areas, you can purchase a Fun Wall Pass from $20 or a Rock Pass from $14. Adventure HQ HometeamNS Khatib, 2 Yishun Walk, Singapore 767944, www.hometeamns.sg/khatib/adventurehq 5. Boulder Movement: Bouldering Gym Image credit: Boulder Movement This capacious bouldering gym in Singapore is popular because of its natural light and range of bouldering walls, which cater to climbers of different abilities. The staff keep an extra sharp eye out for everyone and are always willing to go the extra mile to help. But what climbers laud about Boulder Movement is the fact that the bouldering gym also works to foster a good-hearted community that’s friendly for advanced climbers and beginners. Bouldering prices: From $35 per entry pass. Boulder Movement , multiple locations in Singapore, www.boulderm.com 6. Boulder Planet: Bouldering Gym Image credit: Boulder Planet This bouldering gym in Singapore has a weekly kids’ bouldering class – the BP Rocketeers – that’s in-depth and guided, so kids can improve their climbing skills. Led by trained coaches, your tot will gain all the necessary bouldering knowledge while developing good gross motor skills. Boulder Planet runs a trial bouldering class for kids ($45 for 1 hour), and adults can join the various route setting workshops and adults-only bouldering classes, too. Bouldering prices: $16 for a youth pass (for ages 18 and below; from $33 for an individual pass. Boulder Planet , multiple locations including Sembawang Shopping Centre & Grantral Mall (Tai Seng), www.boulderplanet.sg 7. Climb Central: Bouldering & Rock Climbing Image credit: Climb Central Climb Central offers bouldering and rock climbing for kids who are at least 4 years old, with a weight of more than 20kg and a minimum height of 1.1 metres. All kids must be supervised by an adult (max of two kids per adult). If you’re looking for a spot with some of the highest rock climbing walls in Singapore, Climb Central has it all. Bouldering & rock climbing prices: From $19.62 (child add-on entry pass); from $21.80 (youths); from $27.25 (adults). Climb Central , multiple locations in Singapore including Kallang Wave Mall, Novena Square, Funan and i12 Katong, www.climbcentral.sg 8. Fit Bloc: Rock Climbing & Bouldering Image credit: Fit Bloc Expect one rock climbing wall and three bouldering sections that are suitable for climbers of all ages at this bouldering gym in Singapore! Other than bouldering and rock climbing, you’ll also find a sauna, spin bikes, a basic gym and a swimming pool if you want to cool off afterwards. You can rent the required harness, climbing shoes and an equipment bundle here, too. Rock climbing and bouldering prices: From $28 Fit Bloc , Kent Ridge and Depot Heights Shopping Center , www.fitbloc.com 9. Ground Up Climbing: Rock Climbing & Bouldering Image credit: Ground Up Climbing Rock climbing for kids in Singapore is a breeze at Ground Up Climbing. Their progressive indoor rock climbing classes for kids are suitable for kids aged 5 and up, and include climbing skills and techniques, challenges, games and all sorts of competitions. Children will also focus on mastering balance and movement, and will be taught by coaches who are Singapore Mountaineering Federation and first aid certified. There’s also a bouldering gym with lower heights. Rock climbing and bouldering prices: From $17/adult; Starter sets from $29/adult & $22/youth Ground Up Climbing , Civil Service Club, Level 2, 60 Tessensohn Road, Singapore 217664; www.groundupsg.com 10. boulder+: Bouldering Gym Image credit: The Chevrons (boulder+ Bouldering Gym with two locations) After opening their first bouldering gym in Aperia Mall, Boulder+ opened the biggest bouldering gym in Singapore at The Chevrons. This Singapore bouldering gym has multiple climbing walls and various boulder problems of different difficulties. Boulder+ is open to all climbers aged 7. From beginners to those looking for a challenge, head to the bouldering wall with angles as low as 70 degrees or check out the 60-degree overhang wall for some vertical hang! If you need a shot of caffeine before you climb, there’s a cafe on site. Bouldering prices: $18 for kids’ pass; $35 parent-child pass; day pass $28. boulder+, Aperia Mall, 12 Kallang Avenue & The Chevrons, 48 Boon Lay Way, Singapore, www.boulderplusclimbing.com 11. Kinetics Climbing: Rock Climbing & Bouldering Image credit: Kinetics Climbing Sign your kids up for the Tiny Tots programme at this rock climbing and bouldering gym in Singapore! Suited for kids aged 6 to 9, the programme lets them try their first steps in rock climbing or bouldering under the proper guidance of a friendly coach. The interactive environment will let your child build their strength and core muscles, improve balance and stability and master patience, confidence and concentration. Class ratios are kept at 1:4, and kids will get to progress upwards to Kinetics’ Junior Team too! Rock climbing and bouldering prices: $16.50 (off-peak) & $21 (peak) Kinetics Climbing , 511 Serangoon Road, Singapore 218153, www.kineticsclimbing.com.sg 12. My Little Climbing Room: Kids’ Rock Climbing Image credit: My Little Climbing Room This indoor rock climbing playground is geared toward kids and welcomes littles as young as 3. They’ve got an excellent drop-off programme where kids are guided through the rock climbing session by experienced facilitators. They’ll get to play all sorts of fun games and climbing activities as they build all the right skills to grow in strength. There’s also a trial class available ($38). Rock climbing and bouldering prices: $33/child for a 60-minute session My Little Climbing Room , Promenade @Pelikat,1 83 Jalan Pelikat, #B1-101 Singapore, www.mylittleclimbingroom.com 13. Oyeyo Boulder Home: Bouldering Gym Image credit: Oyeyo Boulder Home Oyeyo Boulder Home is a small bouldering space with a bouldering wall of about 3 metres so it’s a good one to get started with if you are daunted by big heights! Serious climbers look out for their 180-degree climbing wall! There is an option for private bouldering coaching, too, for kids aged 4 to 12 at three levels – Taster, Basic and Intermediate – where kids will learn what to look out for when on the wall, climbing techniques and more. Bouldering prices: $20 for a single-entry pass Oyeyo Boulder Home , 148 Mackenzie Road, Singapore 228724, www.oyeyoboulderhome.com 14. SAFRA Yishun: Highest Outdoor Rock Climbing Image credit: SAFRA Yishun SAFRA Adventure Sports Centre boasts some great outdoor climbing walls for serious adrenaline junkies. Don’t miss the 25m-tall outdoor rock wall. There are also 15m sport climbing walls, a 18m slab wall, and 18m chimney and crack walls. There are two indoor bouldering walls, but the main draw here is the whopping 25-metre outdoor climbing wall, which will really test your climbing skills and agility; however, do note that you’ll need a level 1 SNCS certification and be 7 years old or older to climb here. Rock climbing & bouldering prices: Prices for SAFRA members from $12.95; non-members from $17.85. SAFRA, Yishun , 60 Yishun Avenue 4, Singapore 769027; www.safra.sg 15. BFF Climb: Bouldering Gym + Kids Zone Image credit: BFF Climb BFF Climb is a beginner-friendly bouldering gym with lower walls, so it’s great to get smaller kids started on bouldering. There’s also a Play Zone for kids with a slide to zoom down and a foam pit to jump into. No minimum age is required–kids just need to be at least 11kg. Rock climbing & bouldering prices: $35 for a guided session at Bendemeer & Our Tampines Hub outlets; Single entry from $17.44 BFF Climb , three locations at Bendemeer, Our Tampines Hub & Tampines Yoha, www.bffclimb.com 16. Project Send: Bouldering Gym in Singapore Image credit: Project Send Project Send is one of the newest bouldering gyms in Singapore, located in Esplanade Mall. Their holistic gym offers a variety of fitness classes besides bouldering, and even has a cafe on-site (their Full Day Experience passes include a drink and pastry to go with your climb!). This Singapore bouldering gym often hosts 10-week Kids Track programmes throughout the year, so keep your eyes peeled for their next one on their socials. Bouldering prices: From $35/pax for a Full Day Experience; $40 for a parent-child Buddy Climb (kids 7-12 years old with a parent/guardian) Project Send, 8 Raffles Avenue, #02-29 Esplanade Mall, Singapore 039802, www.projectsend.co 17. VertiClimb Singapore: Gamified Rock Climbing Image credit: VertiClimb Singapore Singapore’s first gamified indoor rock climbing gym, VertiClimb offers detailed levels of planning and automation controls so your immersive climbing experience challenges you both physically and mentally. Littlies can try their hand at rock climbing with a coaching class taught by a national climber. There’s no height limit as all the walls are easy for kids to reach. Equipment is provided too, so all you need to bring is a good pair of socks and deck your kid out in appropriate sportswear. The indoor bouldering centre is only open on weekends and advanced bookings are a must. Rock climbing prices: Prices available upon request. VertiClimb Singapore , 200 Pandan Gardens, #01-02, Singapore 609336 , www.singaporerockclimbing.com 18. SuperPark Singapore: Climbing & Activities Image credit: SuperPark Singapore This one’s not a bouldering gym per se, but SuperPark Singapore does have a cool Augmented Reality wall with various integrated digital aspects. These allow your kiddo to climb to their heart’s content, as the wall has different kinds of games to increase the challenge for climbers! SuperPark prices: Tickets from $30.90 for 100cm and above; $22.90 for below 100cm SuperPark , 3 Temasek Boulevard, Suntec City Mall, #02-477 (North Wing), Singapore www.superpark.com.sg Boulder World: Bouldering Gym (Closed) Image credit: Bouldering World Step into this bouldering gym in Orchard, where you’ll encounter more than 100 boulder problems with different challenge levels. The facilities here also include fully functional fitness rooms, training boards and showers so you can head straight to brunch afterwards! Boulder World can host birthday parties, too, if you’d like some bouldering fun with friends. The Rock School: Rock Climbing & Bouldering (Closed) Image credit: The Rock School This indoor rock climbing and bouldering gym in Our Tampines Hub offers guided intro rock climbing lessons or join their rock climbing camps. Open to tots as young as 2 years right up till age 12, the well-kitted-out rock climbing centre follows structured lesson plans, and your little one will be scaling up their 8-meter walls in no time. Clip ‘n Climb: Bouldering & Rock Climbing (Closed) Clip ‘n Climb has a bouldering space and 19 walls to rock climb, each decked out in different colours and themes with different levels of difficulty, so it’s challenging for everyone. There’s the Morse Code with flashing lights, the Dry Ice wall where you need ice picks, the double-sided Face-to-Face wall and the Spaghetti Junction with dangling ropes for extra difficulty. It’s a full sensory experience and keeps the fun stakes high. There is no age minimum (just weight; kids must be 10kg or above). There’re loads of fun things to do with kids in SG! articles.title: Revamped Museum Of Ice Cream Singapore With Kids: Are the Tickets Worth It?
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Thinking about getting tickets to the Museum of Ice Cream Singapore? Here’s our Museum of Ice Cream review of what to expect at the revamped MOIC in Dempsey when visiting with kids. In case you missed it, the Museum of Ice Cream just had a snazzy revamp. This whopping 60,000 square feet kids’ museum opened in Dempsey on 19 August 2021 and it just had a refresh in April 2025. Here are all the deets about the Museum of Ice Cream including ticket prices, whether you can indeed get FREE ice cream, and more! Read more: Best Places For Gelato & Ice Cream In Singapore Museum of Ice Cream in Dempsey The Museum of Ice Cream property at Dempsey features over 14 never-before-seen installations that “celebrate the joy that ice cream brings”. Expect a whole lot of pink- raid your friends’ wardrobe so you can match for your best IG selfies – it’s all about the gram after all! Ice cream treats are part of your Museum of Ice Cream ticket Image credit: Beate Baldry If you thought the Museum of Ice Cream was all about eating ice cream, you’re not too far off. Ticket holders will get to enjoy ice cream treats (by names such as Denzy Gelato and Ben & Jerry’s, with vegan and allergen-friendly options) as they are guided through the 60- to 90-minute experience by the Museum of Ice Cream staff. And when we say ice cream treats, we mean unlimited servings of ice cream! There are 19 flavours and eight toppings to choose from, including favourites such as Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough and Strawberry Speculoos. There are also other cool treats such as ice cream sandwiches, ice cream tacos and more. Dragon Playground at MOIC Singapore Image credit: Aida Hamid One of the highlights at the Museum of Ice Cream is the fully functional, Singapore-inspired “Dragon Playground” that’s actually a unicorn design with an area to climb up and a small slide to whizz down. There are banana swings and some basketball hoops to shoot while you are there. The whole place is designed for lots of posing for Instagram – it’s pink, pink and more pink. Look out for the red, orange, pink and yellow wall of 10,000 bananas that leads to a craft area for kids to make a little pink ice cream truck out of paper. New highlights at the Museum of Ice Cream Image credit: Aida Hamid Carnival: Kids and adults can both enjoy old-school games here. Bouncy Castle & Infinity Mirror Party Zone: There’s a massive pink bouncy castle the little ones will love, plus a mirror world with dance music for them to burn even more energy off. Banana Maze: Making an appearance for the first time in Singapore, this maze is simply bananas! Get lost in the colourful fruity maze and snap loads of photos along the way. The largest MOIC Sprinkle Pool ever created: It’s filled with multi-coloured giant plastic sprinkles to jump into (and it’s surprisingly relaxing to do so!) MOIC Passport: MOIC workshops: Included in the price of your ticket are free workshops! Join an ice cream-making workshop, make keychains, create squishy paintings and craft edible slime from 3 to 25 May 2025. How much does the Museum of Ice Cream cost? Tickets cost $35 per entry for Singapore Residents and $43 for General Admission. Kids aged 2 and below enter free. Premium MOIC tickets cost from $44, which gives you access to five exclusive ice cream flavours, extra toppings and a complimentary drink. Singapore Residents get 10% off weekday General and Premium tickets from now till 30 May with the code SGSPRINKLE10 at checkout online. Get tickets to MOIC here . So are tickets to the Museum of Ice Cream worth it? Image credit: Beate Baldry We asked our two kiddos if they liked the experience. They said it was 10 out of 10. Unlimited ice cream will do that to kids. We found the price a little steep, but rest assured the kids will have a ball of a time especially if you’re out of ideas of what to do with the kids . Where is the Museum of Ice Cream Singapore? Image credit: Aida Hamid Find the Museum of Ice Cream Singapore at 100 Loewen Road, Dempsey, Singapore 248837 Opening Hours: Friday – Tuesday 10am – 7pm; Wednesday 10am – 3pm; Thursday 10am – 2.30pm www.museumoficecream.sg Read more: The post Revamped Museum Of Ice Cream Singapore With Kids: Are the Tickets Worth It? appeared first on Sassy Mama .

articles.title: Telltale Signs Your Child May Need Speech Therapy & What To Do Next
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Stuttering, speech delays, articulation struggles – sound familiar? Here’s how to spot the signs your child might need speech therapy, and how the therapists at Ray of Joy Therapy can help! Parents, are you noticing that your child is not meeting certain communication milestones or seems to be falling behind their peers? Whether they’re struggling with speech delay, having trouble engaging in conversations or finding it hard to pronounce words, these challenges can impact their confidence. But here’s the good news–early intervention can make all the difference! Here are some signs that your child might need speech therapy, and how the MOE-experienced therapists at Ray of Joy Therapy can help. Read more: Guide to SPED Schools, Early Intervention Centres, Inclusive & Special Needs Schools in Singapore Common signs that your child may need speech therapy Communication challenges can impact your child in the long run, but how can you tell if they need professional help? While it’s important to keep in mind that children develop at their own pace, certain signs may indicate the need for early intervention. One of the most common challenges is speech delay. You might notice your child falling behind their peers when it comes to speaking or understanding language. Some children also face difficulty forming complete sentences or using incomplete phrases. Most kids begin speaking around 1 year old and start forming sentences by 2. If your child isn’t hitting these milestones, it might be a good idea to seek support. Other common signs to look out for include trouble following instructions, struggling with articulation, unintelligible speech and stuttering. Parents should also observe if their child has difficulty maintaining conversations, making friends or understanding social cues, which may be accompanied by frustration when trying to communicate. Why early detection is important Communication challenges can impact your child in the long run, making it harder for them to build self-confidence, make friends, express their feelings and even succeed in school. Early intervention is essential in helping your child communicate effectively, which in turn supports their emotional and social development. Speech therapists are beneficial at addressing these challenges and ensuring your child gets the support they need. At Ray of Joy Therapy, the team, made out of three founders, brings extensive MOE school and preschool experience, offering unique insights into the communication skills children need. Therapy sessions can be held at their One Holland Village space or at your home. These sessions are designed to help parents understand how communication skills impact children at every educational stage – from playground interactions to classroom participation – providing therapy that prepares children for real-world communication challenges. Get a free speech therapy consultation for your child Still unsure if your child needs professional help? Ray of Joy Therapy offers a free 15-minute consultation call to discuss your concerns and determine what’s best for your child’s needs. They also provide a free online milestone tracker on the website, where you can monitor your child’s progress with expert guidance. articles.title: Guide To SPED Schools, Early Intervention Centres, Inclusive & Special Needs Schools In Singapore
articles.author: Sassy Mama
articles.content: Looking for an inclusive or SPED school, early intervention centre or special needs school in Singapore? Consult our list to find the right one for your child. Special education schools in Singapore (SPED) are part of a quickly evolving landscape, as 2019 marked the first year that Singaporean students with moderate-to-severe special needs were required to attend school under the government’s Compulsory Education framework . These days, younger learners and non-Singaporean students also have plenty of options for special education preschools and early intervention centres that can help differently-abled children thrive in supportive and safe environments – Singapore has 19 government-funded SPED schools, too, which you can view here . Alongside special education schools, inclusive schools, which are ‘mainstream schools’ where diverse students learn side by side in the same classroom with extra support offered, there is a notable culture shift towards neurodivergent acceptance and inclusion . Do note that there is some controversy around applied behaviour analysis (ABA) therapy to ‘fix’ autistic attributes and teach autistic kids skills to lessen problematic behaviour like self-harm. Some parents and the neurodiversity movement do not support the use of ABA therapy and instead seek out interventions that use neurodiverse-affirming approaches . As always, do your research to understand what therapy you feel would best suit your child. We discuss the different approaches here. Wondering where to find a SPED school, inclusive preschool or an early intervention programme that will suit your child’s learning needs? We’ve rounded up a wide range of special needs schools in Singapore – from inclusive schools to specialist special needs preschools and early prevention programmes – which cater to Singaporeans, Permanent Residents and non-Singaporean students of differing abilities unless stated otherwise. Keep scrolling for all the deets! Read More: Dyslexia In Singapore: How I Helped My Daughter Learn To Read Jump to: – Inclusive Schools in Singapore – Special Needs Preschools in Singapore – Special Needs Schools & Institutions in Singapore – Early Intervention Centres – Frequently Used Terms for Special Needs Learning in Singapore Read more: Differently Wired Kids: To Label Or Not To Label? One Family’s Story Inclusive schools in Singapore Melbourne International School: WASC-accredited school with a differentiated learning approach Image credit: Melbourne International School Melbourne International School is a small inclusive school that caters to students aged 3 to 12 years old. They offer a nurturing and supportive learning environment where each student feels psychologically safe, heard and accepted, tailoring their lessons to each student’s unique needs and learning pace. The Early Years and Years 1 to 5 programmes are inclusive mainstream programmes, but they also offer an alternative route for students who are better suited for the special education programme. All programmes include collaborative therapy with a speech therapist, occupational therapist and psychology professionals. Parents love their small class ratio of 1 teacher to 4 to 8 students, ensuring that each student gets personalised attention to reach their fullest potential. Students are better able to focus, providing a conducive and comfortable learning environment for all. Since one size does not fit all, their educators adopt a differentiated and multi-sensory approach to teaching. In addition to a team of therapists, the educators also collaborate with specialist teachers in music and art to further enhance their teaching skills. A testament to the integrity of their programmes, Melbourne International School is a recipient of the WASC accreditation. This recognition assures parents that their curriculum is appropriate and executed through robust education programmes, reinforcing their mission to provide equal educational opportunities to all neurodivergent learners. Melbourne International School, 75C Loewen Road, Singapore 248853, Tel: (+65) 6634 8891, enquiries@melis.edu.sg , WhatsApp: (+65) 8318 4737, www.melis.edu.sg All Hands Together: Small class sizes and personalised learning approach Image credit: All Hands Together All Hands Together is an inclusive boutique school for children aged 2 to 18 that offers two learning pathways: mainstream academic education and functional education including an early intervention programme. The mainstream programme prepares students for workplace success, while the functional education programme focuses on helping children gain life-ready skills, promoting independence and confidence. The school supports children with diverse needs, including autism, ADHD, GDD, Down syndrome, and other learning, developmental, and socio-emotional challenges including anxiety. Their small class sizes and low teacher-to-student ratio of 1:4 or 1:2 ensure a personalised learning approach, equipping students to thrive in a supportive environment. All Hands Together places a strong emphasis on partnerships and works closely with families and therapists to provide effective solutions that help children learn in a way that suits them best. Every child has their own Individualised Education Programme (IEP) and a Curriculum Manager, who oversees their development through a combination of formal assessments and a dynamic review process. The school offers additional services like speech, occupational, and music therapy, as well as extracurricular activities on Fridays to introduce new hobbies. The school facilities include an occupational therapy gym, a sensory and quiet room, a library, and a great outdoor space including a large field. These include approaches such as DIR Floortime, Hanen Program, PROMPT and Social Thinking. KidsFirst , 8 Hong Kong Street, Singapore 059651 , Tel: (+65) 9166 5597, www.kidsfirst.co Thumbs Up Therapy Singapore: Mobile paediatric service The special needs practice aims to bridge the gap between children, caregivers, schools and therapists. Thumbs Up Therapy’s mobile, in-home paediatric service helps children independently perform activities such as learning in school, managing and organising their belongings, playtime and self-care – dressing up, eating or going to the toilet without help – all of which are crucial in helping them grow into successful young adults. Thumbs Up Therapy Singapore , 24 Jalan Kuning, Singapore 278169, Tel: ( +65) 8803 8447, www.thumbsuptherapy.sg Frequently Used Terms for Special Needs Learning in Singapore We strongly suggest checking out Singapore’s Association for Persons with Special Needs ( APSN) and the M.O.E.’s Parent’s Guide for Children with Special Education Needs , which answers the question “ What does it mean to have special education needs?” with the following points: They have been diagnosed with a disability They show greater difficulty in learning as compared to the majority of their peers of the same age (e.g. difficulties in social, language, academic or physical abilities). They require different or additional resources beyond what is generally available for the majority of their peers of the same age. Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA) Commonly practised as a therapeutic intervention for Autism, ABA is a type of therapy that focuses on improving specific behaviours, such as social skills, communication, reading and academics, as well as adaptive learning skills. Do note that there is some controversy around applied behaviour analysis (ABA) therapy to ‘fix’ autistic attributes and teach autistic kids skills to lessen problematic behaviour like self-harm. Some parents and the neurodiversity movement do not support the use of ABA therapy and instead seek out interventions that use neurodiverse-affirming approaches . We discuss the different approaches. here. Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) Autism spectrum disorder (or just autism) is a broad range of conditions characterised by challenges with social skills, repetitive behaviours, speech and nonverbal communication. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development . Early Intervention In Singapore, early intervention programmes are defined as seeking to equip infants and young children with special needs with improved motor, communication, social, self-help and cognitive skills. Early intervention activities are designed to maximise their developmental growth potential and minimise the development of secondary disabilities. Inclusive education This is an educational model or philosophy where special needs students are in the same classroom as non-special-needs (general education) students, with the belief that it fosters understanding and tolerance and better prepares students of all abilities to function in the world beyond school. Mainstream school “ Mainstreaming ” is the practice of placing students with special education needs in a general education classroom during certain times, based on their skills (while at others placing them in separate special education classes). This is in contrast to “inclusion”. Neurotypical A relatively new term used to describe individuals of “typical” developmental, intellectual and cognitive abilities (in contrast to someone who may be on the autism spectrum or has other developmental differences characterising them as “neurodiverse”). Occupational Therapists These specialists can help children achieve developmental milestones such as fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination. In a broader sense, occupational therapists work with people to help make everyday living easier. Shadow teachers Shadow teachers work directly with a single special needs student in a mainstream or inclusive educational setting, focusing on social development and any particular difficulties that might arise from a child’s specific abilities Speech Therapists Speech therapists work with people of all ages with communication or swallowing difficulties, including comprehension and expression, articulation and phonology, fluency, and voice. Speech therapists can also help kids with other issues with spoken and written language, including dyslexia, dyspraxia, and auditory processing disorder. Other Resources For Individuals With Special Needs In Singapore Autism Resource Centre (Singapore) Autism Resource Centre (Singapore) is a non-profit charity organisation that helps individuals on the autism spectrum maximise their potential in life by providing education, employment and empowerment of family caregivers and professionals. From helping families find a suitable early intervention school to offering training for caregivers, Autism Resource Centre (Singapore) is readily available to provide the support every family might need. articles.content: Looking for a trendy Korean hair salon or a classic barbershop experience, here’s our list of recommended hair salons in Singapore for both men and women offering hair colour services, haircuts, hair treatments and more. Keeping your hair looking fresh in Singapore’s relentless humidity is no easy feat, and finding the right hair salon to help you do that? That’s a whole other challenge! Singapore has no shortage of beauty treatments — from facials and spa days (yes, even Japanese onsens !) to mobile beauty services that come right to your doorstep. But sometimes, nothing beats a little me-time spent at a great hair salon in Singapore, giving your hair the attention they deserve. Whether you’re after a quick haircut, a vibrant new hair colour, or searching for the best hair salons for hair treatments, we’ve rounded up the best hair salons in Singapore that know how to deliver. From trendy Korean hair salons to barbershops offering the best haircuts for men, here are the best hair salons in Singapore where you can get some hair TLC! Read more: Where To Go For Baby And Kids’ Haircuts In Singapore Best Hair Salons In Singapore 2025: 99 Percent Hair Studio: Singapore’s only Wella flagship hair salon Image credit: Vaniday – 99 Percent Hair Studio Ever heard of Wella Professionals? This iconic German haircare brand has been around for over 140 years and is a go-to in salons worldwide for haircare and styling products. articles.title: Things To Do In Da Nang With Kids: Best Time To Visit, Flights, Hoi An, My Khe Beach & More
articles.author: Jessica Fang
articles.content: From the stunning sights of Hoi An to the Miami-like My Khe Beach, here are all the best things to do in Da Nang, Vietnam and why it’s a great destination for families. Find out what to do in Da Nang with kids, Singapore t0 Da Nang flights and more! We can almost guarantee that you’ve heard about the latest travel hot spot, Da Nang, Vietnam. This up-and-comer is turning heads for its fantastic beaches, unique attractions and luxury hotels, and it’s less than a 3-hour direct flight from Singapore! With the beautiful My Khe Beach, the stunning scenery of Ba Na Hills, Marble Mountains and more, plus kid-friendly resorts, it’s easy to see why Da Nang makes such an easy travel destination for families. We break down all the best things to do in Da Nang with kids, its popular neighbouring city Hoi An, how to get to Da Nang from Singapore, the weather in Da Nang, where to stay in Da Nang and family-friendly travel tips! P.S. While you’re at it check out some great islands near Singapore ! Jump to: – Singapore to Da Nang Flights – Best time to travel to Da Nang – Things to do in Da Nang with kids – Where to stay in Da Nang – Day trip from Da Nang to Hoi An – Family travel tips for Da Nang Singapore to Da Nang flights Image credit: saiko3p via Getty Images What makes Da Nang such an appealing holiday destination for travellers from Singapore is its relatively close proximity. We love that there are direct flights from Singapore to Da Nang available daily. Flights from Singapore to Da Nang are about 2 hours and 45 minutes long on Singapore Airlines and Vietjet, no transits needed. The flights aren’t too lengthy which is a bonus if you’re travelling with young children. Best time to visit Da Nang: Da Nang Weather Image credit: Hyatt Regency Resort and Spa The best time to visit Da Nang is between January and August. The dry season in Da Nang lasts from February to May and is perfect for outdoor activities with daytime temperatures averaging between 25°C to 30°C. We love that the evenings are cool with low humidity during this time, unlike the tropical weather we’re used to in Singapore. The hottest months in Da Nang are between June and August, with temperatures hitting 40°C. The rainy season in Da Nang starts from around September and lasts till December/January. During this time temperatures will drop to around 18°C to 23°C, with the city being susceptible to typhoons. Things to do in Da Nang with kids My Khe Beach: Best things to do in Da Nang Image credit: Nguyen Minh Tam via Getty Images They say Da Nang is the “Miami of Vietnam” and it’s because of its gorgeous white sand beaches, and that’s without a doubt thanks to the acclaimed My Khe Beach. My Khe Beach has earned a reputation as one of the best things to do in Da Nang for its powdery sand, rows of palm trees, calm waves and picturesque view of the mountains and open sea. Stretching a whopping 10 kilometres long, My Khe Beach is a great place to go with the family in Da Nang for sunbathing, sunrise and sunset, beach sports and water sports. My Khe Beach, Võ Nguyên Giáp, Hoà Hải, Ngũ Hành Sơn, Đà Nẵng 550000, Vietnam Ba Na Hills & Golden Bridge: Kid-friendly things to do in Da Nang Image credit: Vietnam Tourism Giant rock hands, a cable car, a French village, an alpine coaster ride, a fantasy park and more: there’s so much to do a Ba Na Hills in Da Nang with the kids! Ba Na Hills is located about an hour’s drive from Da Nang city, or 20 minutes if you head to the Hoi An cable car station near Ba Na Hills SunWorld and take the gondola up. That said, you’ll want to set aside at least half a day to cover all the best things to do at Ba Na Hills. First up is the famous Golden Bridge; you know–that iconic bridge held up by two massive rock hands. We recommend taking the cable car up to enjoy stunning views of the valley below. The Golden Bridge is located near the Marseille cable car station. It gets busy with tourists, so we recommend heading here as early as possible. You can then take the cable car to other parts of Ba Na Hills. A must-visit is the French village at Morin Station, and we guarantee the kids will love Fantasy Park Da Nang, which has a natural history museum with dinosaurs and arcade games–all included in the cost of your Ba Na Hills entry ticket. There’s also the Alpine Coasters ride and picturesque gardens up here. There are hotels at Ba Na Hills if you wish to stay the night, but honestly, a day trip here is sufficient. Ba Na Hills & Golden Bridge Da Nang, Thôn An Sơn, Hòa Vang, Da Nang, Vietnam, www.banahills.sunworld.vn Marble Mountains Da Nang: Scenic things to do in Da Nang Image credit: Jessica Fang The perfect spot for enjoying Da Nang’s stunning natural beauty, Marble Mountains Da Nang comprises five limestone peaks and is adorned with Buddhist religious sites. Over here, you’ll find caves and trails, as well as towers and pagodas that date all the way back to the 17th century. All these are accented by overgrown vines and moss and marble statues that give the mountain its ancient city vibe. At the foothills of the mountain, you’ll find numerous marble shops and stalls selling souvenirs and trinkets. Just be warned: you’ll have to climb a lot of stairs. We don’t recommend bringing young kids here as it’s not stroller-friendly at all, and some of the trails are very rugged and with slippery rocks. Older kids should be able to tackle the mountains, though–they can even climb through a cave! Trust us, the amazing sights of Marble Mountains are what make it one of the best things to do in Da Nang. Marble Mountains Da Nang, 81 Huyền Trân Công Chúa, Hoà Hải, Ngũ Hành Sơn, Đà Nẵng 550000, Vietnam Dragon Bridge Da Nang: Fire-breathing dragon bridge Image credit: Wikipedia The Dragon Bridge in Da Nang is pretty hard to miss as you can see it en route from the airport to My Khe Beach. The bridge isn’t just a cool monument of the city; it’s also where you can catch the FREE fire and water show! This one’s not to be missed, because the Dragon Bridge in Da Nang actually breathes fire! The dragon fire-breathing show starts at 9pm and is about 15 minutes long. You can view it from the shores of the Han River or from the parallel Tran Thi Ly Bridge. Dragon Bridge Da Nang, Đ. Nguyễn Văn Linh, Phước Ninh, Hải Châu, Đà Nẵng 550000, Vietnam Lady Buddha Da Nang: Giant statue in Da Nang Image credit: Traveloka If you’re hanging out at My Khe Beach, you’ll notice a giant white statue far away on the peninsula. That’s Lady Buddha, the tallest Buddha statue in Vietnam that stands 67 metres tall. Lady Buddha Da Nang is one of the three Linh Ung Pagodas of Da Nang, and is a religious site for Buddhists. Entry to the area is completely free and is easy to explore with kids. Lady Buddha Da Nang, Vườn Lâm Tỳ Ni, Hoàng Sa, Thọ Quang, Sơn Trà, Đà Nẵng, Vietnam Da Nang Cathedral (Pink Church Da Nang) While exploring Da Nang city, be sure to stop by the Da Nang Cathedral. Built in 1923 during the French colonial times, the Da Nang Cathedral features Gothic architecture and its signature pink facade. The cathedral is free to enter–perfect if you’re looking for free things to do in Da Nang with kids. Da Nang Cathedral, 156 Trần Phú, Hải Châu 1, Hải Châu, Đà Nẵng 550000, Vietnam Da Nang night markets: Shopping in Da Nang Shop for souvenirs and try some great street food at a night market in Da Nang. Located near the iconic Dragon Bridge, Son Tra Night Market is one of the more popular night markets in Da Nang. Over here, you can find some fab local seafood, local fare, clothes, handicrafts and more. Son Tra Night Market, Mai Hắc Đế, An Hải Trung, Sơn Trà, Đà Nẵng 550000, Vietnam Where to stay in Da Nang: Family-friendly hotels in Da Nang Hyatt Regency Danang Resort and Spa Image credit: Hyatt Regency Danang Resort and Spa With an inflatable water playground, a massive swimming pool, a well-equipped kids club, kids activities and more, Hyatt Regency Danang Resort and Spa is easily one of the most kid-friendly hotels in Da Nang. This beachfront resort is undoubtedly luxurious with rooms, suites and villas to choose from, as well as the exclusive VIE Spa, complimentary wellness activities (sound baths, yoga and more!) and world-class on-site dining options (Le Petit Chef, themed nights with BBQ dinners and more). However, the show-stopper here is really the kid-friendly facilities. Over at the Camp Hyatt kids club, kids can let loose at the small indoor playground with a ball pit, lots of toys and two bouncy castles. We love that there are complimentary kids’ activities and workshops throughout the day, so you can drop the kids off and then go relax at the spa. There’s a massive playground next to the kids’ club, as well as the kids’ pool with an inflatable water playground. You’ll also find an array of fun lawn games, a rock-climbing wall and a small football field here. The resort also has a gaming arcade that’s free to use for all guests plus a vegetable garden with a rabbit coop! Kids will also love frolicking on the spacious white sand beach and you can easily tire them out just at the humongous main swimming pool (which also has a little ‘faux beach’ corner) alone. Hyatt Regency Danang Resort and Spa, 5 Trường Sa, Street, Ngũ Hành Sơn, Đà Nẵng 550000, Vietnam, www.hyatt.com InterContinental Danang Sun Peninsula Resort Image credit: InterContinental Danang Sun Peninsula Resort InterContinental Danang Sun Peninsula Resort is a secluded beach resort in Da Nang located on the Son Tra Peninsula. The resort is surrounded by nature and oozes luxury, offering recreational land and sea activities, cultural and culinary experiences, a fab kids club, wellness activities and more. InterContinental Danang Sun Peninsula Resort, Bãi Bắc, Thọ Quang, Sơn Trà, Đà Nẵng 550000, Vietnam, www.danang.intercontinental.com Fusion Resort & Villas Da Nang Image credit: Fusion Resort & Villas Da Nang Take your pick from villas with plunge pools and spacious suites at Fusion Resort & Villas Da Nang. This beach resort in Da Nang is located just opposite a golf course and has a luxurious spa, a kids club and complimentary daily activities that include beach sports, cycling and more. Fusion Resort & Villas Da Nang, Trường Sa, Hoà Hải, Ngũ Hành Sơn, Đà Nẵng 550000, Vietnam, www.fusionresorts.com Hilton Da Nang Image credit: Hilton Da Nang Hilton Da Nang is located in the city, just next to Dragon Bridge Da Nang, putting you at a convenient distance from all of Da Nang’s attractions. From Hilton Da Nang you’ll get fab views of the river as well as the ocean in the distance. Hilton Da Nang, 50 Bạch Đằng, Hải Châu 1, Hải Châu, Đà Nẵng 50000, Vietnam, www.hilton.com Day trip from Da Nang to Hoi An: Things to do in Hoi An Image credit: Vietnam Tourism A popular addition to any Da Nang itinerary is a day trip to Hoi An. There are plenty of things to do in Hoi An with the kids. A visit to the beautiful Hoi An Ancient Town is a must, where you can admire the town’s traditional architecture and the sight of traditional boats floating down the canals. Visitors flock here to witness the Hoi An Lantern Festival which takes place on the 14th day of each lunar month. If you’re planning to stay in Hoi An, you’ll want to bring the kids to the Hoi An Impression Theme Park. Each night there’s the magnificent Memories Show, which features over 500 performers, dazzling lights and special effects that tell a story of Hoi An’s 400-year history. You can also check out the Hoi An Night Market for great street food in Hoi An. There are some great resorts in Hoi An, including Four Seasons Hoi An which is located by the beach in Hoi An, Anantara Hoi An, Renaissance Hoi An Resort & Spa and Beach Palm Villa Hoi An. How to get from Da Nang to Hoi An: The journey from Da Nang to Hoi An takes about 30 to 45 minutes by car, and you can easily take a taxi or Grab to get there. There are also public buses from Da Nang to Hoi An if you’re going the budget route. The nearest airport to Hoi An is Da Nang International Airport, and the weather in Hoi An is similar to Da Nang. Family travel tips for Da Nang How long do you need in Da Nang? A short 3D2N Da Nang itinerary is sufficient if you’re just looking for a relaxing short weekend escapade. If it’s your first time in Da Nang then we recommend planning a 4D3N Da Nang itinerary to cover both Ba Na Hills and Hoi An; or a 5D4N itinerary to factor in time for beach activities and other Da Nang attractions. How to get around Da Nang? If you’re coming from Singapore then great news: Grab is available in Da Nang. It’s easy to book a car to take you to all the main attractions; all you have to do is open your app and you’re good to go. Of course, you can also opt for tour packages from the hotel or tour agencies. What currency to use in Da Nang? Vietnamese Dong (VND) is used in Da Nang. USD is also widely accepted by hotels, shops and restaurants in Da Nang. The post Things To Do In Da Nang With Kids: Best Time To Visit, Flights, Hoi An, My Khe Beach & More appeared first on Sassy Mama .

articles.title: This Preschool Has Sensory Gardens, Swimming Pools, A Parent Cafe & More For Nurturing Little Ones

articles.content: Thanks to their robust curriculum, purpose-built facilities and diverse range of co-curricular activities, Australian International School’s Early Learning Village gives little ones a head start to thrive. Choosing the right preschool in Singapore for your little one will set the tone for their academic journey in the years to come. If you’re looking for a school that allows your child to feel like it’s a home away from home, look no further than Australian International School ‘s Early Learning Village. Here, little ones from Infant Care to 5 years old will achieve their developmental and academic milestones while having a ton of fun! Spearheaded by Stuart Armistead, the new Head of Early Years, the Early Learning Village is centred around building strong connections within the community and ensuring that young learners continue to benefit from a nurturing and innovative learning environment. Read more: Guide To International Schools In Singapore Curriculum of globally recognised programmes More than just a preschool that takes care of your child while you go about your day, Australian International School boasts an effective curriculum that draws from over 30 years of experience in early childhood education. Taking the best from the globally recognised Reggio Emilia philosophy, the Australian Early Years Learning Framework (EYLF) and the IB Primary Years Programme (IB PYP), their Early Years curriculum nurtures and supports children in meeting key milestones through fun and engaging ways. Fabulous facilities & co-curricular activities In addition to its holistic curriculum and dedicated team of educators, Australian International School’s Early Learning Village is known for their purpose-built facilities. From outdoor play decks to sensory gardens and a 20-metre swimming pool, there’s no shortage of opportunities for young learners to explore the world around them. Beyond learning in the classroom, children can choose from a range of enriching co-curricular activities to discover and develop their passions like art, sports and music. They can hone their gross motor skills with swimming, ballet, soccer and basketball, or tap into their creativity through storytelling sessions and drama classes. A tight-knit, welcoming village for every family Image credit: Australian International School Australian International School is proud of its global community which comprises over 50 nationalities, teaching children to appreciate diversity from a young age. By growing up with people from different cultures, children develop empathy, open-mindedness and cultural awareness, equipping them to thrive in an interconnected world. As the saying goes, “It takes a village to raise a child.” That’s why the school is intentional about creating opportunities for connection, encouraging frequent collaboration between parents and educators. Parents receive weekly newsletters and daily updates from the StoryPark platform. They also have an on-site Parent Café, where you can grab a cuppa or an afternoon snack with fellow parents before picking the kids up from school. The Early Learning Village at Australian International School is ready to equip your child with the skills, confidence and curiosity they need to succeed. Book a tour today to get a sneak peek into a day in the life of a young learner at Australian International School’s Early Learning Village!
